soln_description:
Let's assume $a_{1}<a_{2}<\cdots<a_{n}$, then $a=-a_{1}-a_{2}-\cdots-a_{n}$ is the smallest integer of the form $t_{1} a_{1}+t_{2} a_{2}+\cdots+t_{n} a_{n}$. $a+2 a_{1}=a_{1}-a_{2}-\cdots-a_{n}$ is also an integer of the form $t_{1} a_{1}+t_{2} a_{2}+\cdots+t_{n} a_{n}$. Generally, $a+2 a_{1}+2 a_{2}$ is also an integer of the form $t_{1} a_{1}+t_{2} a_{2}+\cdots+t_{n} a_{n}$. And so on, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\underset{1 \uparrow}{a}<\underbrace{a+2 a_{1}<a+2 a_{2}<\cdots<a+2 a_{n}}_{n \uparrow} \\
<\underbrace{a+2 a_{n}+2 a_{1}<\cdots<a+2 a_{n}+2 a_{n-1}}_{n-1 \uparrow} \\
<\underbrace{a+2 a_{n}+2 a_{n-1}+2 a_{1}<\cdots<a+2 a_{n}+2 a_{n-1}+2 a_{n-2}}_{n-2 \uparrow} \\
<\cdots<\underbrace{a+2 a_{n}+\cdots+2 a_{3}+2 a_{1}<a+2 a_{n}+\cdots+2 a_{3}+2 a_{2}}_{2} \\
<\underbrace{a+2 a_{n}+2 a_{n-1}+\cdots+2 a_{2}+2 a_{1}}_{1} \\
=a+2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) \\
=a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

Each integer in the above expression is a different number of the form $t_{1} a_{1}+t_{2} a_{2}+\cdots+t_{n} a_{n}$ (where $t_{i}$ is 1 or -1, $i=1,2, \cdots, n$). There are
$$
\begin{array}{l}
1+n+(n-1)+(n-2)+\cdots+2+1 \\
=1+\frac{n(n+1)}{2}=\frac{n^{2}+n+2}{2}
\end{array}
$$

distinct numbers.
It is easy to see that when $a$ is even, these $\frac{n^{2}+n+2}{2}$ distinct integers are all even; when $a$ is odd, these $\frac{n^{2}+n+2}{2}$ distinct integers are all odd.
informal_statement: Five. (15 points) Suppose there are $n$ distinct positive integers $a_{1}, a_{2}$, $\cdots, a_{n}$. Then among the integers of the form $t_{1} a_{1}+t_{2} a_{2}+\cdots+t_{n} a_{n}$ (where $t_{1}$ takes 1 or $-1, i=1,2, \cdots, n)$, there exist $\frac{n^{2}+n+2}{2}$ distinct integers that are either all odd or all even.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Five. (15 points) Suppose there are $n$ distinct positive integers $a_{1}, a_{2}$, $\cdots, a_{n}$. Then among the integers of the form $t_{1} a_{1}+t_{2} a_{2}+\cdots+t_{n} a_{n}$ (where $t_{1}$ takes 1 or $-1, i=1,2, \cdots, n)$, there exist $\frac{n^{2}+n+2}{2}$ distinct integers that are either all odd or all even. -/
theorem number_theory_326183 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) (a : Fin n → ℤ)
    (ha : ∀ i j, a i = a j → i = j) (ha1 : ∀ i, 0 < a i) :
    {x | ∃ t : Fin n → ℤ, (∀ i, t i = 1 ∨ t i = -1) ∧ x = ∑ i, t i * a i}.ncard =
    (n ^ 2 + n + 2) / 2 := by

informal_statement: Circle $O$ is located on the coordinate plane with center at $(2,3)$.  One endpoint of a diameter is at $(-1,-1)$.  What are the coordinates of the other endpoint of this diameter?  Express your answer as an ordered pair.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Circle $O$ is located on the coordinate plane with center at $(2,3)$.  One endpoint of a diameter is at $(-1,-1)$.  What are the coordinates of the other endpoint of this diameter?  Express your answer as an ordered pair. -/
theorem algebra_13398 (O : ℝ × ℝ) (hO : O = (2, 3)) (d : ℝ × ℝ) (hd : d = (-1, -1)) :
    (d.1 + 2 * (O.1 - d.1), d.2 + 2 * (O.2 - d.2)) = (5, 7) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_13398 (O : ℝ × ℝ) (hO : O = (2, 3)) (d : ℝ × ℝ) (hd : d = (-1, -1)) :
    (d.1 + 2 * (O.1 - d.1), d.2 + 2 * (O.2 - d.2)) = (5, 7) := by
  rw [hO, hd]
  norm_num

soln_description:
[Solution] When $x-a$ divides the integer-coefficient polynomial $f(x)$, the remainder is $f(a)$, so when $x^{13}+$ 1 is divided by $x-1$, the remainder is $1^{13}+1=2$.
Therefore, the answer is $(D)$.

soln_description:
Answer: Petya outpaced Vasya by 1 m.

Solution. In the second race, Petya eliminates the lag from Vasya by running 100 m (during this time, Vasya will run 90 m). 10 m remain to the finish line - 10 times less than at the start of the 1st race. Therefore, the lead will be 10 times less, i.e., 1 m.

Scoring. 11 points for a complete solution.
informal_statement: 1. Pete and Vasya competed in a 100 m race. When Pete finished, Vasya was 10 m behind him. During the second race, Pete started exactly 10 m behind Vasya. Who finished first in the second race and by how many meters did he outpace his opponent? (Assume that each boy ran at the same constant speed both times).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Pete and Vasya competed in a 100 m race. When Pete finished, Vasya was 10 m behind him. During the second race, Pete started exactly 10 m behind Vasya. Who finished first in the second race and by how many meters did he outpace his opponent? (Assume that each boy ran at the same constant speed both times). -/
theorem algebra_173671 {p v : ℝ} (hp : p > 0) (hv : v > 0)
    (h1 : p * 100 = v * 90) (h2 : p * 90 = v * 100 + x) :
    x = 1 := by

soln_description:
21. Let $x=\frac{1}{a}, y=\frac{1}{b}, z=\frac{1}{c}$. From the given $a b+b c+c a=a b c$, we get $x+y+z=1$.
$$\frac{x^{4}+y^{4}}{x^{3}+y^{3}}-\frac{x+y}{2}=\frac{(x-y)^{2}\left(x^{2}+x y+z^{2}\right)}{2\left(x^{3}+y^{3}\right)} \geqslant 0$$

Thus,
$$\frac{x^{4}+y^{4}}{x^{3}+y^{3}} \geqslant \frac{x+y}{2}$$

Similarly,
$$\begin{array}{l}
\frac{y^{4}+z^{4}}{y^{3}+z^{3}} \geqslant \frac{y+z}{2} \\
\frac{z^{4}+x^{4}}{z^{3}+x^{3}} \geqslant \frac{z+x}{2}
\end{array}$$

Therefore,
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{a^{4}+b^{4}}{a b\left(a^{3}+b^{3}\right)}+\frac{b^{4}+c^{4}}{b c\left(b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}+\frac{c^{4}+a^{4}}{c a\left(c^{3}+a^{3}\right)}= & \frac{x^{4}+y^{4}}{x^{3}+y^{3}}+\frac{y^{4}+z^{4}}{y^{3}+z^{3}}+\frac{z^{4}+x^{4}}{z^{3}+x^{3}} \geqslant \\
& \frac{x+y}{2}+\frac{y+z}{2}+\frac{z+x}{2}= \\
& x+y+z=1
\end{aligned}$$
informal_statement: 21. Let $a, b, c$ be positive numbers, satisfying $a b + b c + c a = a b c$, prove the inequality: $\frac{a^{4}+b^{4}}{a b\left(a^{3}+b^{3}\right)}+$ $\frac{b^{4}+c^{4}}{b c\left(b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}+\frac{c^{4}+a^{4}}{c a\left(c^{3}+a^{3}\right)} \geqslant 1$. (2006 Polish Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 21. Let $a, b, c$ be positive numbers, satisfying $a b + b c + c a = a b c$, prove the inequality: $\frac{a^{4}+b^{4}}{a b\left(a^{3}+b^{3}\right)}+$ $\frac{b^{4}+c^{4}}{b c\left(b^{3}+c^{3}\right)}+\frac{c^{4}+a^{4}}{c a\left(c^{3}+a^{3}\right)} \geqslant 1$. (2006 Polish Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem inequalities_601205 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + b * c + c * a = a * b * c) :
    1 ≤ (a ^ 4 + b ^ 4) / (a * b * (a ^ 3 + b ^ 3)) +
        (b ^ 4 + c ^ 4) / (b * c * (b ^ 3 + c ^ 3)) +
        (c ^ 4 + a ^ 4) / (c * a * (c ^ 3 + a ^ 3)) := by

soln_description:
Prove that this problem is not easy to tackle directly. If we transform one side of the inequality to 1, and then observe the characteristics of the new inequality structure, it is easier to find the proof idea.

The original inequality is equivalent to
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt[n]{\frac{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)}} \\
+\sqrt[n]{\frac{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)}} \\
+\sqrt[n]{\frac{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)}} \leqslant 1
\end{array}$$

Notice that
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt[n]{\frac{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)}} \\
\leqslant \frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{a_{1}}{a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}}{a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}}\right), \\
\sqrt[n]{\frac{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)}} \\
\leqslant \frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{b_{1}}{a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}}+\frac{b_{2}}{a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{b_{n}}{a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}}\right), \\
\sqrt[n]{\frac{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{n}}{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)}} \\
\leqslant \frac{1}{n}\left(\frac{c_{1}}{a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}}+\frac{c_{2}}{a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{c_{n}}{a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}}\right) .
\end{array}$$

By adding the above three inequalities, we obtain inequality (1).
Therefore, the original inequality holds.
informal_statement:
For example, $10 a_{i}, b_{i}, c_{i}>0(i=1,2, \cdots, n)$. Prove:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\quad \sqrt[n]{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)} \geqslant \sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}}+\sqrt[n]{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{n}}+ \\
\sqrt[n]{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{n}} .
\end{array}$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- For example, $10 a_{i}, b_{i}, c_{i}>0(i=1,2, \cdots, n)$. Prove:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\quad \sqrt[n]{\left(a_{1}+b_{1}+c_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}+b_{2}+c_{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{n}+b_{n}+c_{n}\right)} \geqslant \sqrt[n]{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}}+\sqrt[n]{b_{1} b_{2} \cdots b_{n}}+ \\
\sqrt[n]{c_{1} c_{2} \cdots c_{n}} .
\end{array}$$ -/
theorem inequalities_601696 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) (a b c : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i, 0 < a i) (hb : ∀ i, 0 < b i) (hc : ∀ i, 0 < c i) :
    (∏ i, (a i + b i + c i)) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / n) ≥
    (∏ i, a i) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / n) +
    (∏ i, b i) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / n) +
    (∏ i, c i) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / n) := by

informal_statement:
For positive real numbers $b_1,b_2,\ldots,b_n$ define
$$a_1=\frac{b_1}{b_1+b_2+\ldots+b_n}\enspace\text{ and }\enspace a_k=\frac{b_1+\ldots+b_k}{b_1+\ldots+b_{k-1}}\text{ for }k>1.$$Prove that $a_1+a_2+\ldots+a_n\le\frac1{a_1}+\frac1{a_2}+\ldots+\frac1{a_n}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- For positive real numbers $b_1,b_2,\ldots,b_n$ define
$$a_1=\frac{b_1}{b_1+b_2+\ldots+b_n}\enspace\text{ and }\enspace a_k=\frac{b_1+\ldots+b_k}{b_1+\ldots+b_{k-1}}\text{ for }k>1.$$Prove that $a_1+a_2+\ldots+a_n\le\frac1{a_1}+\frac1{a_2}+\ldots+\frac1{a_n}$ -/
theorem inequalities_57194 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (b : ℕ → ℝ)
    (hb : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, 0 < b i) (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (ha1 : a 1 = b 1 / (∑ i ∈ Icc 1 n, b i)) (hak : ∀ k > 1, a k = (∑ i ∈ Icc 1 k, b i) / (∑ i ∈ Icc 1 (k - 1), b i)) :
    ∑ i ∈ Icc 1 n, a i ≤ ∑ i ∈ Icc 1 n, 1 / a i := by

soln_description:
4. Let $S=\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}$.

Since $\sum_{i<j}\left(a_{i}+a_{j}\right)=(n-1) S$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i<j} \frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{a_{i}+a_{j}}=\sum_{i<j} \frac{1}{4}\left[a_{i}+a_{j}-\frac{\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2}}{a_{i}+a_{j}}\right] \\
\quad=\frac{n-1}{4} S-\frac{1}{4} \sum_{i<j} \frac{\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2}}{a_{i}+a_{j}} .
\end{array}
$$

Also, since $(n-1) \sum_{i<j} a_{i} a_{j}=\frac{n-1}{2}\left(S^{2}-\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right)$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i<j} a_{i} a_{j}=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i<j}\left[a_{i}^{2}+a_{j}^{2}-\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2}\right] \\
=\frac{n-1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i<j}\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Adding the two equations, we get
$n \sum_{i<j} a_{i} a_{j}=\frac{n-1}{2} S^{2}-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i<j}\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2}$.
Thus, $\frac{n}{2 S} \sum_{i<j} a_{i} a_{j}=\frac{n-1}{4} S-\frac{1}{4} \sum_{i<j} \frac{\left(a_{i}-a_{j}\right)^{2}}{S}$.
Comparing equations (1) and (2), since $S \geqslant a_{i}+a_{j}$, we have:
$$
\sum_{i<j} \frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{a_{i}+a_{j}} \leqslant \frac{n}{2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)} \sum_{i<j}^{1} a_{i} a_{j} .
$$
informal_statement:
4. For positive real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$, prove:
$$
\sum_{i<j} \frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{a_{i}+a_{j}} \leqslant \frac{n}{2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)} \sum_{i<j} a_{i} a_{j} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 4. For positive real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$, prove:
$$
\sum_{i<j} \frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{a_{i}+a_{j}} \leqslant \frac{n}{2\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)} \sum_{i<j} a_{i} a_{j} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_315609 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) (a : Fin n → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i, 0 < a i) :
    ∑ i, ∑ j, (if i < j then a i * a j / (a i + a j) else 0) ≤
    (n / (2 * ∑ i, a i)) * ∑ i, ∑ j, (if i < j then a i * a j else 0) := by

soln_description:
We already see that 3 is a solution: let's show that it is the only one.

Let $n$ be such an integer: there exists $a \geq 0$ such that $2^{n}+1=a^{2}$. Clearly $a 
eq 0$. But then $2^{n}=(a-1)(a+1)$, so $a+1$ and $a-1$ are positive divisors of a power of 2, hence they are powers of 2. Since they differ by 2, they can only be 2 and 4 (indeed, if $2^{x}+2=2^{y}$, then $y \geq 2$ because $2^{y}>2$ and $x \leq 1$ because $2^{y}-2^{x} 
eq 0[4]$ and $x 
eq 0$ so $x=1$ and $y=2$) so $a=3$ and $n=3$.
informal_statement: Find the positive integers $n$ such that $2^{n}+1$ is a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the positive integers $n$ such that $2^{n}+1$ is a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_160769 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    IsSquare (2 ^ n + 1) ↔ n = 3 := by

soln_description:
# Solution:

Let the second worker make 100 parts in $x$ hours, and the first worker in $x-2$ hours.

$\frac{100}{x-2}-\frac{100}{x}=\frac{5}{2} ; \frac{40}{x-2}-\frac{40}{x}=1 ; x^{2}-2 x-80=0, x=1+9=10$. Answer: 8 and 10 hours.
informal_statement:
1. One worker in two hours makes 5 more parts than the other, and accordingly spends 2 hours less to manufacture 100 parts. How much time does each worker spend on manufacturing 100 parts?

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. One worker in two hours makes 5 more parts than the other, and accordingly spends 2 hours less to manufacture 100 parts. How much time does each worker spend on manufacturing 100 parts?

# -/
theorem algebra_262436 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h1 : 2 * a = b + 5) (h2 : 100 / a = 100 / b - 2) :
    100 / a = 8 ∧ 100 / b = 10 := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { II. Let } A=\sqrt[3]{x(3+\sqrt{8 x-3})-1}, \\
B=\sqrt[3]{x(3-\sqrt{8 x-3})-1} . \\
\text { Then } A^{3}+B^{3}=6 x-2, A B=1-2 x .
\end{array}
$$
$$
\text { Let } t=A+B \text {. }
$$

Notice that,
$$
(A+B)^{3}=A^{3}+B^{3}+3 A B(A+B) \text {. }
$$

Then $t^{3}-3(1-2 x) t-(6 x-2)=0$, which is
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(t-1)\left(t^{2}+t+6 x-2\right)=0 . \\
\text { Also, } t^{2}+t+6 x-2=\left(t+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+6\left(x-\frac{3}{8}\right),
\end{array}
$$

When $x=\frac{3}{8}$, $t=A+B=2 \sqrt[3]{3 x-1}=1$.
Thus, $t^{2}+t+6 x-2>0$.
Therefore, for any $x \geqslant \frac{3}{8}$, we have
$$
t^{2}+t+6 x-2>0 \text {. }
$$

Hence, $t=1$.
In conclusion, the set of real solutions to the original equation is
$$
\left\{x \left\lvert\, x \geqslant \frac{3}{8}\right.\right\} .
$$
informal_statement:
II. (40 points) Find the real solution of the equation
$$
\sqrt[3]{x(3+\sqrt{8 x-3})-1}+\sqrt[3]{x(3-\sqrt{8 x-3})-1}=1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- II. (40 points) Find the real solution of the equation
$$
\sqrt[3]{x(3+\sqrt{8 x-3})-1}+\sqrt[3]{x(3-\sqrt{8 x-3})-1}=1
$$ -/
theorem algebra_303723 (x : ℝ) (hx : 0 ≤ 8 * x - 3) :
    (x * (3 + Real.sqrt (8 * x - 3)) - 1) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) +
    (x * (3 - Real.sqrt (8 * x - 3)) - 1) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) = 1 ↔
    x ≥ 3 / 8 := by

soln_description:
Suppose that there is an $x$ such that $0\sin x$, we can reduce by $\cos x-\sin x$ and get

$$
1=\frac{\cos x+\sin x}{\cos x \sin x}=\frac{1}{\sin x}+\frac{1}{\cos x} .
$$

But $0\frac{\pi}{4}$ then $0<\frac{\pi}{2}-x<\frac{\pi}{4}$. As the sine, cosine, tangent and cotangent of $\frac{\pi}{2}-x$ are equal to the sine, cosine, tangent and cotangent of $x$ in some order, the contradiction carries over to this case, too.
informal_statement:
. Does there exist an angle $\alpha \in(0, \pi / 2)$ such that $\sin \alpha, \cos \alpha, \tan \alpha$ and $\cot \alpha$, taken in some order, are consecutive terms of an arithmetic progression?

Answer: No.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- . Does there exist an angle $\alpha \in(0, \pi / 2)$ such that $\sin \alpha, \cos \alpha, \tan \alpha$ and $\cot \alpha$, taken in some order, are consecutive terms of an arithmetic progression?

Answer: No. -/
theorem algebra_236339 : ¬ ∃ α : Real, α ∈ Ioo 0 (π/2) ∧ ∃ a d : ℝ,
  {x | x = sin α ∨ x = cos α ∨ x = tan α ∨ x = cot α} = {a, a+d, a+2*d, a+3*d} := by

soln_description:
First, $343=7^{3}$, so the group $(\mathbb{Z} / 343 \mathbb{Z})^{*}$ is cyclic and isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 294 \mathbb{Z}\left(294=6 \cdot 7^{2}\right)$. Let $x$ be a primitive root and $\alpha$ such that $a=x^{\alpha}$:

$$
\mathrm{a}^{70} \equiv 1[343] \Longleftrightarrow 70 \alpha \equiv 0[294] \Longleftrightarrow 21 \mid \alpha
$$

This gives us 14 equivalence classes mod 294 for $\alpha$, which correspond to 14 equivalence classes modulo 343 for $a$.

Now, for the modulo 128, it is slightly different since

$$
\left((\mathbb{Z} / 128 \mathbb{Z})^{*}, x\right) \simeq(\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} /(32) \mathbb{Z},+)
$$

We are looking for all pairs $(\varepsilon, k)$ with $\varepsilon \in \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$ and $k \in \mathbb{Z} / 32 \mathbb{Z}$ that satisfy $70 \varepsilon \equiv 0[2]$ and $70 k \equiv 0[32]$. We quickly see that there are two choices for $\varepsilon$ and two choices for $k$, which corresponds to 4 equivalence classes mod 128.
informal_statement: How many classes are there modulo 343 such that $a^{70} \equiv 1 \pmod{343}$? Same question modulo 128.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- How many classes are there modulo 343 such that $a^{70} \equiv 1 \pmod{343}$? Same question modulo 128. -/
theorem number_theory_151638 : {x : ℤ | x^70 ≡ 1 [ZMOD 343]}.ncard = 144 := by

/- 6. (6 points) The sum of two numbers is 432, and the quotient is 5, the larger number $=$ $\qquad$ , the smaller number $=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_273593 {x y : ℕ} (h₀ : x + y = 432) (h₁ : x / y = 5) :
    x = 360 ∧ y = 72 := by

Let $M$ be the maximum possible magnitude of $a$. Find all $a$ such that $|a| = M$. -/
theorem algebra_59464 (a b : ℂ) (ha : a^3 - 3 * a * b^2 = 36) (hb : b^3 - 3 * b * a^2 = 28 * .I) :
    ‖a‖ ≤ 3 ∧ (a = 3 ∨ a = 3 * Complex.exp (Complex.I * π / 3) ∨ a = 3 * Complex.exp (-Complex.I * π / 3)) := by

informal_statement: 25. Suppose $x^{3}-a x^{2}+b x-48$ is a polynomial with three positive roots $p, q$, and $r$ such that $p<q<r$. What is the minimum possible value of $1 / p+2 / q+3 / r$ ?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 25. Suppose $x^{3}-a x^{2}+b x-48$ is a polynomial with three positive roots $p, q$, and $r$ such that $p<q<r$. What is the minimum possible value of $1 / p+2 / q+3 / r$ ? -/
theorem algebra_189792 (a b : ℝ) (p q r : ℝ)
    (h₀ : p > 0) (h₁ : q > 0) (h₂ : r > 0) (h₃ : p < q ∧ q < r)
    (h₄ : p^3 - a * p^2 + b * p - 48 = 0) (h₅ : q^3 - a * q^2 + b * q - 48 = 0)
    (h₆ : r^3 - a * r^2 + b * r - 48 = 0) :
    3 / 2 ≤ 1 / p + 2 / q + 3 / r := by

soln_description:
[Proof] By contradiction, assume $a^{2}+b^{2} \geqslant \frac{\pi^{2}}{4}$. Since
$$a \sin x+b \cos x=\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}} \sin (x+\varphi)$$

where $\varphi$ is a fixed real number depending only on $a, b$, such that
$$\cos \varphi=\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}, \sin \varphi=\frac{b}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}} .$$

Since $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}} \geqslant \frac{\pi}{2}$, there exists a real number $x_{0}$, such that
$$\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}} \sin \left(x_{0}+\varphi\right)=\frac{\pi}{2}$$

i.e., $\square$
$$a \sin x_{0}+b \cos x_{0}=\frac{\pi}{2}$$

This implies $\cos \left(a \sin x_{0}\right)=\sin \left(b \cos x_{0}\right)$,
which contradicts the assumption! Therefore, $a^{2}+b^{2}<\frac{\pi^{2}}{4}$.
informal_statement: 9-128 For any real number $x$, we have $\cos (a \sin x)>\sin (b \cos x)$. Prove: $a^{2}+b^{2}<\frac{\pi^{2}}{4}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 9-128 For any real number $x$, we have $\cos (a \sin x)>\sin (b \cos x)$. Prove: $a^{2}+b^{2}<\frac{\pi^{2}}{4}$. -/
theorem inequalities_600655 {a b : ℝ} (ha : ∀ x, cos (a * sin x) > sin (b * cos x)) :
    a^2 + b^2 < (π^2)/4 := by

    f.eval 1 = 1296 := by

soln_description:
Prove: Let $a=\frac{x}{y}, b=\frac{y}{z}, c=\frac{z}{x}$,
where $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers. Then the original inequality becomes
$$
(x-y+z)(y-z+x)(z-x+y) \leqslant x y z \text {. }
$$

Let $u=x-y+z, v=y-z+x, w=z-x+y$.
Since the sum of any two of these three numbers is positive, at most one of them can be negative.

If exactly one is negative, then $u v w \leqslant 0 < x y z$. The inequality is proved.

If all three numbers are greater than 0, then by the arithmetic mean-geometric mean inequality we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{u v}=\sqrt{(x-y+z)(y-z+x)} \\
\leqslant \frac{1}{2}[(x-y+z) ;(y-z+x)]=x .
\end{array}
$$

Similarly, $\sqrt{v w} \leqslant y, \sqrt{w u} \leqslant x$.
informal_statement:
2. Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $abc=1$. Prove:
$$
\left(a-1+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b-1+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c-1+\frac{1}{a}\right) \leqslant 1 .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $abc=1$. Prove:
$$
\left(a-1+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b-1+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c-1+\frac{1}{a}\right) \leqslant 1 .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_324967 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (habc : a * b * c = 1) :
    (a - 1 + 1 / b) * (b - 1 + 1 / c) * (c - 1 + 1 / a) ≤ 1 := by

soln_description:
Let $x$ and $y$ be the two numbers we are looking for. Then we get the system of equations

$$
x+y=20 \quad(1) \quad ; \quad x^{2}+y^{2}=202
$$

Rearranging (1) for $y$ and substituting into (2) yields

$$
x^{2}+(20-x)^{2}=202 \Rightarrow 2 x^{2}-40 x+198=0 \Rightarrow x^{2}-20 x+99=0
$$

This quadratic equation has the solutions $x_{1}=9$ and $x_{2}=11$ with $y_{1}=11$ and $y_{2}=9$.

The numbers we are looking for are 9 and 11. They satisfy the conditions of the problem, as confirmed by the check.
informal_statement:
## Task 1 - V00901

The sum of two numbers is 20, and the sum of their squares is 202. Solve the problem mathematically.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 1 - V00901

The sum of two numbers is 20, and the sum of their squares is 202. Solve the problem mathematically. -/
theorem algebra_175872 {x y : ℤ} (h₀ : x + y = 20) (h₁ : x^2 + y^2 = 202) :
    x = 9 ∧ y = 11 ∨ x = 11 ∧ y = 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_175872 {x y : ℤ} (h₀ : x + y = 20) (h₁ : x^2 + y^2 = 202) :
    x = 9 ∧ y = 11 ∨ x = 11 ∧ y = 9 := by
  have h2 : y = 20 - x := by linarith
  rw [h2] at h₁
  -- Now we have x^2 + (20 - x)^2 = 202
  -- Expanding this:
  -- x^2 + (400 - 40x + x^2) = 202
  -- Therefore:
  -- 2x^2 - 40x + 400 - 202 = 0
  -- 2x^2 - 40 x + 198 =0
  -- Then dividing by 2:
  -- x^2 - 20 x + 99 = 0
  -- Solving the quadratic:
  -- x = [20 ± sqrt(4)] / 2 = [20 ± 2] / 2
  -- Therefore:
  -- x can be 9 or 11
  have h5 : 2 * x^2 - 40 * x + 198 = 0 := by
    nlinarith
  -- Divide the quadratic equation by 2:
  have h6 : x^2 - 20 * x + 99 = 0 := by
    linarith
  have h7 : x = 9 ∨ x = 11 := by
    have h8 : x^2 - 20 * x + 99 = 0 := h6
    have h9 : x^2 - 20 * x + 99 = (x - 9) * (x - 11) := by ring
    rw [h9] at h8
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 h8) with h10 h11
    · -- x - 9 = 0
      left
      linarith
      all_goals
      try tauto
    · -- x - 11 = 0
      right
      linarith
      all_goals
      try tauto
  cases' h7 with h8 h9
  · -- x = 9
    have hx : x = 9 := h8
    have hy : y = 11 := by
      linarith [h₀, hx]
    left
    exact ⟨hx, hy⟩
  · -- x = 11
    have hx : x = 11 := h9
    have hy : y = 9 := by
      linarith [h₀, hx]
    right
    exact ⟨hx, hy⟩

soln_description:
2. To store a password written in a $32$-letter alphabet ("ё" is identified with "е"), each letter is represented by its ordinal number - a pair of digits (i.e., А - 01, Б - 02, etc.). This results in a sequence of digits $y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots$ Simultaneously, according to the rule $x_{i+1}=r_{10}\left(a x_{i}+b\right)$, a sequence of decimal digits $\left(x_{i}\right)$ is generated, with the minimal period of 10, where $r_{10}(x)$ is the remainder of $x$ divided by $10$, and $a, b$ are natural numbers. After that, according to the rule $c_{i}=r_{10}\left(x_{i}+y_{i}\right)$, the sequence $\left(c_{i}\right)$ is calculated, which is then stored in the computer's memory. Vasya chose a very short word for his password, so he had to repeat it twice when entering it. Help him recover the forgotten password if the stored sequence $\left(c_{i}\right)$ is: 285283198418497 5. Provide the recovered password in lowercase letters (one word).

Answer: yacht.
informal_statement: 2. To store a password written in a $32$-letter alphabet ("ё" is identified with "е"), each letter is represented by its ordinal number - a pair of digits (i.e., А - 01, Б - 02, etc.). This results in a sequence of digits $y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots$ At the same time, according to the rule $x_{i+1}=r_{10}\left(a x_{i}+b\right)$, a sequence of decimal digits $\left(x_{i}\right)$ is generated, with the minimal period of 10, where $r_{10}(x)$ is the remainder of $x$ divided by $10, a, b$ are natural numbers. After that, according to the rule $c_{i}=r_{10}\left(x_{i}+y_{i}\right)$, the sequence $\left(c_{i}\right)$ is calculated, which is then stored in the computer's memory. Vasya chose a very short word for his password, so he had to repeat it twice when entering it. Help him recover the forgotten password if the stored sequence $\left(c_{i}\right)$ is: 285283198418497 5. Provide the recovered password in lowercase letters (one word).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. To store a password written in a $32$-letter alphabet ("ё" is identified with "е"), each letter is represented by its ordinal number - a pair of digits (i.e., А - 01, Б - 02, etc.). This results in a sequence of digits $y_{1}, y_{2}, \ldots$ At the same time, according to the rule $x_{i+1}=r_{10}\left(a x_{i}+b\right)$, a sequence of decimal digits $\left(x_{i}\right)$ is generated, with the minimal period of 10, where $r_{10}(x)$ is the remainder of $x$ divided by $10, a, b$ are natural numbers. After that, according to the rule $c_{i}=r_{10}\left(x_{i}+y_{i}\right)$, the sequence $\left(c_{i}\right)$ is calculated, which is then stored in the computer's memory. Vasya chose a very short word for his password, so he had to repeat it twice when entering it. Help him recover the forgotten password if the stored sequence $\left(c_{i}\right)$ is: 285283198418497 5. Provide the recovered password in lowercase letters (one word). -/
theorem number_theory_240014 (y : ℕ → ℕ) (hy : ∀ i, y i = i % 32)
    (x : ℕ → ℕ) (hx : ∀ i, x i = (a * x (i - 1) + b) % 10)
    (c : ℕ → ℕ) (hc : ∀ i, c i = (x i + y i) % 10)
    (h : ∃ p, Function.Periodic c p) (hp : p = 10) :
    ∃ n, n > 0 ∧ c n = 285283198418497 := by

soln_description:
To construct a triangular number table, add 1 to the left: (1, 3, ..., 2n-1) as the first row. Then
$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{n}= & 2[(2 n-1)+((2 n-1)+(2 n \\
& -3))+\cdots+((2 n-1)+\cdots+3+
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 1)]-[1+3+\cdots+(2 n-1)] \\
= & 2 \cdot \frac{1}{6} n(n+1)[2(2 n-1)+1] \\
& -n^{2} \\
= & \frac{1}{3} n\left(4 n^{2}-1\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement: Example 6 Find the value of $1^{2}+3^{2}+\cdots+(2 n-1)^2$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Find the value of $1^{2}+3^{2}+\cdots+(2 n-1)^2$ -/
theorem algebra_306542 (n : ℕ) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (2 * i + 1) ^ 2 = n * (4 * n ^ 2 - 1) / 3 := by

soln_description:
1. Let's denote the number of blue candies as \( b \).
2. According to the problem, there are \( 14\% \) more yellow candies than blue candies. Therefore, the number of yellow candies \( y \) can be expressed as:
   \[
   y = 1.14b
   \]
3. Similarly, there are \( 14\% \) fewer red candies than blue candies. Therefore, the number of red candies \( r \) can be expressed as:
   \[
   r = 0.86b
   \]
4. The total number of candies in the jar is the sum of red, blue, and yellow candies. Since we are looking for the percentage, we can assume the total number of candies is 1 (or 100%):
   \[
   r + b + y = 1
   \]
5. Substitute the expressions for \( r \) and \( y \) in terms of \( b \) into the total equation:
   \[
   0.86b + b + 1.14b = 1
   \]
6. Combine like terms:
   \[
   (0.86 + 1 + 1.14)b = 1
   \]
   \[
   3b = 1
   \]
7. Solve for \( b \):
   \[
   b = \frac{1}{3}
   \]
8. Now, substitute \( b \) back into the expression for \( y \):
   \[
   y = 1.14b = 1.14 \times \frac{1}{3} = \frac{1.14}{3} = 0.38
   \]
9. Therefore, the percentage of yellow candies in the jar is:
   \[
   y = 0.38 \times 100\% = 38\%
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{38\%} \).
informal_statement: A jar contains red, blue, and yellow candies. There are $14\%$ more yellow candies than blue candies, and $14\%$ fewer red candies than blue candies. Find the percent of candies in the jar that are yellow.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A jar contains red, blue, and yellow candies. There are $14\%$ more yellow candies than blue candies, and $14\%$ fewer red candies than blue candies. Find the percent of candies in the jar that are yellow. -/
theorem algebra_56749 (total_candies : ℝ) (h₀ : total_candies ≠ 0)
    (yellow_candies blue_candies red_candies : ℝ)
    (h₁ : yellow_candies = blue_candies * 1.14) (h₂ : red_candies = blue_candies * 0.86)
    (h₃ : total_candies = yellow_candies + blue_candies + red_candies) :
    yellow_candies / total_candies * 100 = 38 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_56749 (total_candies : ℝ) (h₀ : total_candies ≠ 0)
    (yellow_candies blue_candies red_candies : ℝ)
    (h₁ : yellow_candies = blue_candies * 1.14) (h₂ : red_candies = blue_candies * 0.86)
    (h₃ : total_candies = yellow_candies + blue_candies + red_candies) :
    yellow_candies / total_candies * 100 = 38 := by

  have eq1 : total_candies = blue_candies * 3 := by
    rw [h₃, h₁, h₂]
    ring

  have h5 : blue_candies ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h
    have h6 : blue_candies = 0 := by
      linarith
    have h7 : total_candies = 0 := by
      rw [eq1]
      rw [h6]
      norm_num
    contradiction
  
  rw [h₁, eq1]
  field_simp [h5]
  ring_nf

soln_description:
Obviously, the integers that can divide $n$ are
$$
7 l_{1} \times 11^{l_{2}} \times 13^{l_{3}}, \quad 0 \leqslant l_{1} \leqslant 3,0 \leqslant l_{2} \leqslant 2,0 \leqslant l_{3} \leqslant 4 \text {. }
$$

According to the multiplication rule, the number of integers that can divide $n$ is
$$
4 \times 3 \times 5=60
$$
informal_statement:
Example 1-6 $n=7^{3} \times 11^{2} \times 13^{4}$, find the number of integers that divide $n$ evenly.

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1-6 $n=7^{3} \times 11^{2} \times 13^{4}$, find the number of integers that divide $n$ evenly.

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem number_theory_150384 {n : ℕ} (hn : n = 7^3 * 11^2 * 13^4) :
    Set.ncard {k | n % k = 0} = 60 := by

informal_statement:
Let x; y; z be real numbers, satisfying the relations
$x \ge 20$
$y \ge 40$
$z \ge 1675$
x + y + z = 2015
Find the greatest value of the product P = $xy z$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let x; y; z be real numbers, satisfying the relations
$x \ge 20$
$y \ge 40$
$z \ge 1675$
x + y + z = 2015
Find the greatest value of the product P = $xy z$ -/
theorem inequalities_45826 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : x ≥ 20) (hy : y ≥ 40) (hz : z ≥ 1675)
    (hsum : x + y + z = 2015) :
    x * y * z ≤ 721480000 / 27 := by

soln_description:
[Proof] $n^{3}+\frac{3}{2} n^{2}+\frac{1}{2} n-1=\frac{n(n+1)(2 n+1)}{2}-1$
$$
=\frac{n(n+1)}{2}(2 n+1)-1 \text {. }
$$

Since for any integer $n, \frac{n(n+1)}{2}$ is an integer, the original expression is an integer.
(1) The end of the equation can also be written as $\frac{2 n(2 n+1)(2 n+2)}{8}-1$, and among $2 n, 2 n+1, 2 n+2$, at least one number is a multiple of 3, and since 3 and 8 are coprime, $\frac{2 n(2 n+1)(2 n+2)}{8}$ is an integer divisible by 3.
Thus, the original expression equals an integer multiple of 3 minus 1, so when divided by 3, it must leave a remainder of 2.
informal_statement: $5 \cdot 3$ Prove: $n^{3}+\frac{3}{2} n^{2}+\frac{1}{2} n-1$ is an integer for any positive integer $n$, and when divided by 3, the remainder is 2.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $5 \cdot 3$ Prove: $n^{3}+\frac{3}{2} n^{2}+\frac{1}{2} n-1$ is an integer for any positive integer $n$, and when divided by 3, the remainder is 2. -/
theorem algebra_217094 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    ∃ k : ℤ, n^3 + (3/2)*n^2 + (1/2)*n - 1 = k ∧ k % 3 = 2 := by

soln_description:
Let $\cos \frac{\pi}{7}=x$, then the original expression $=2 x^{2}-1+3 x$
$$
-4 x^{3}-x=4 x^{3}+2 x^{2}-1 \text {. }
$$

Notice: $\cos \frac{4 \pi}{7}=-\cos \frac{3 \pi}{7}$,
i.e., 2
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(2 x^{2}-1\right)^{2}-1=3 x-4 x^{3}, \\
\therefore(x+1)\left(8 x^{3}-4 x+1\right)=0 .
\end{array}
$$

But $x \neq-1,8 x^{3}-4 x^{2}-4 x+1=0$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \text { the original expression } & =-\frac{1}{2}\left(8 x^{3}-4 x^{2}-4 x\right)-1 \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$
(Turn to page 41)
informal_statement: Example 1. Find the value of $\cos \frac{2 \pi}{7}+\cos \frac{4 \pi}{7}+\cos \frac{6 \pi}{7}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 1. Find the value of $\cos \frac{2 \pi}{7}+\cos \frac{4 \pi}{7}+\cos \frac{6 \pi}{7}$ -/
theorem algebra_313338 : cos (2 * π / 7) + cos (4 * π / 7) + cos (6 * π / 7) = -1 / 2 := by

informal_statement: Solve the equation $\sqrt{2 - x^2} + \sqrt{x^2 + 8} = 4$ for $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the equation $\sqrt{2 - x^2} + \sqrt{x^2 + 8} = 4$ for $x$. -/
theorem algebra_227 (x : ℝ) (hx : 2 - x ^ 2 ≥ 0 ∧ x ^ 2 + 8 ≥ 0) : Real.sqrt (2 - x ^ 2) + Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) = 4 ↔ x = 1 ∨ x = -1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_227 (x : ℝ) (hx : 2 - x ^ 2 ≥ 0 ∧ x ^ 2 + 8 ≥ 0) : Real.sqrt (2 - x ^ 2) + Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) = 4 ↔ x = 1 ∨ x = -1 := by
  constructor
  · -- Assume the equation holds, prove x = 1 or x = -1
    intro h
    have ha1 : Real.sqrt (2 - x ^ 2) ≥ 0 := by positivity
    have hb1 : Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) ≥ 0 := by positivity
    have h1 : Real.sqrt (2 - x ^ 2) = 4 - Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) := by linarith
    have h2 : (Real.sqrt (2 - x ^ 2)) ^ 2 = (4 - Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8)) ^ 2 := by
      rw [h1]
    have h3 : (Real.sqrt (2 - x ^ 2)) ^ 2 = 2 - x ^ 2 := by
      rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
      linarith
    have h4 : (4 - Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8)) ^ 2 = 16 - 8 * Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) + (Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8)) ^ 2 := by
      ring
    have h5 : (Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8)) ^ 2 = x ^ 2 + 8 := by
      rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
      linarith
    rw [h3, h4, h5] at h2
    -- Now we have 2 - x^2 = 16 - 8 * sqrt(x^2 + 8) + (x^2 + 8)
    -- which simplifies to 8 * sqrt(x^2 + 8) = 22 + 2x^2
    have h6 : 8 * Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) = 22 + 2 * x ^ 2 := by
      nlinarith
    have h7 : Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8) = (22 + 2 * x ^ 2) / 8 := by
      linarith
    have h8 : (Real.sqrt (x ^ 2 + 8)) ^ 2 = ((22 + 2 * x ^ 2) / 8) ^ 2 := by
      rw [h7]
    rw [h5] at h8
    -- Now we have x^2 + 8 = ((22 + 2x^2) / 8)^2
    -- which leads to the polynomial equation
    have h9 : (x ^ 2 + 8) = ((22 + 2 * x ^ 2) / 8) ^ 2 := by
      linarith
    -- Now multiply both sides by 64 to clear the denominator
    have h10 : x ^ 4 + 6 * x ^ 2 - 7 = 0 := by
      nlinarith [h9]
    -- Factor the polynomial
    have h11 : (x ^ 2 + 7) * (x ^ 2 - 1) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [h10]
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 h11) with h12 h13
    · -- Case where x^2 + 7 = 0, which is impossible
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg x]
    · -- Case where x^2 - 1 = 0, so x^2 = 1
      have h14 : x ^ 2 = 1 := by
        linarith
      have h15 : x = 1 ∨ x = -1 := by
        have h : x ^ 2 = 1 := h14
        have : x = 1 ∨ x = -1 := by
          rw [sq_eq_one_iff] at h
          exact h
        assumption
      exact h15
  · -- Assume x = 1 or x = -1, prove the equation holds
    rintro (h | h)
    · -- Case x = 1
      rw [h]
      have h1 : Real.sqrt (2 - (1 : ℝ) ^ 2) = 1 := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      have h2 : Real.sqrt ((1 : ℝ) ^ 2 + 8) = 3 := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      rw [h1, h2]
      all_goals norm_num
    · -- Case x = -1
      rw [h]
      have h3 : Real.sqrt (2 - (-1 : ℝ) ^ 2) = 1 := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      have h4 : Real.sqrt ((-1 : ℝ) ^ 2 + 8) = 3 := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_eq_iff_sq_eq] <;> norm_num
      rw [h3, h4]
      all_goals norm_num

soln_description:
## Solution

Canonical equations of a line:

$\frac{x-x_{0}}{m}=\frac{y-y_{0}}{n}=\frac{z-z_{0}}{p}$

where $\left(x_{0} ; y_{0} ; z_{0}\right)_{\text {- are coordinates of some point on the line, and }} \vec{s}=\{m ; n ; p\}$ - its direction vector.

Since the line belongs to both planes simultaneously, its direction vector $\vec{s}$ is orthogonal to the normal vectors of both planes. The normal vectors of the planes are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \overrightarrow{n_{1}}=\{8 ;-1 ;-3\} \\
& \overrightarrow{n_{2}}=\{1 ; 1 ; 1\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let's find the direction vector $\vec{s}:$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{s}=\overrightarrow{n_{1}} \times \overrightarrow{n_{2}}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
i & j & k \\
8 & -1 & -3 \\
1 & 1 & 1
\end{array}\right|= \\
& =i \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & -3 \\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right|-j \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}
8 & -3 \\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right|+k \cdot\left|\begin{array}{cc}
8 & -1 \\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right|=
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=2 i-11 j+9 k=\{2 ;-11 ; 9\}
$$

Let's find some point on the line $\left(x_{0} ; y_{0} ; z_{0}\right)$. Let $z_{0}=0$, then

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
8 x_{0}-y_{0}-3 \cdot 0-1=0 \\
x_{0}+y_{0}+0+10=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
8 x_{0}-y_{0}-1=0 \\
x_{0}+y_{0}+10=0
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
8 x_{0}-y_{0}-1=0 \\
9 x_{0}+9=0
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
8 x_{0}-y_{0}-1=0 \\
x_{0}=-1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
8 \cdot(-1)-y_{0}-1=0 \\
x_{0}=-1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{l}
y_{0}=-9 \\
x_{0}=-1
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the point $(-1 ;-9 ; 0)$ belongs to the line. We obtain the canonical equations of the line:

$\frac{x+1}{2}=\frac{y+9}{-11}=\frac{z}{9}$

Problem Kuznetsov Analytic Geometry 13-14
informal_statement:
## Task Condition

Write the canonical equations of the line.

$8 x-y-3 z-1=0$

$x+y+z+10=0$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task Condition

Write the canonical equations of the line.

$8 x-y-3 z-1=0$

$x+y+z+10=0$ -/
theorem algebra_154124 (x y z : ℝ) (h₀ : 8 * x - y - 3 * z - 1 = 0) (h₁ : x + y + z + 10 = 0) :
    (x + 1) / 2 = (y + 9) / (-11 : ℝ) ∧ (y + 9) / (-11 : ℝ) = z / 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_154124 (x y z : ℝ) (h₀ : 8 * x - y - 3 * z - 1 = 0) (h₁ : x + y + z + 10 = 0) :
    (x + 1) / 2 = (y + 9) / (-11 : ℝ) ∧ (y + 9) / (-11 : ℝ) = z / 9 := by
  have h2 : y = -x - z - 10 := by linarith
  rw [h2] at h₀
  have hx : x = (2 * z - 9) / 9 := by
    linarith
  have h_eq1 : (x + 1) / 2 = z / 9 := by
    rw [show x + 1 = (2 * z) / 9 by
      linarith [hx]
    ]
    ring_nf
    <;> linarith
  have hy : y + 9 = (-11 * z) / 9 := by
    have h3 : x = (2 * z - 9) / 9 := hx
    have h4 : y = -x - z - 10 := h2
    rw [h4]
    rw [h3]
    linarith [h₀, h₁, hx]
  have h_eq2 : (y + 9) / (-11 : ℝ) = z / 9 := by
    rw [show (y + 9 : ℝ) = (-11 * z) / 9 by
      linarith [hy]
    ]
    ring_nf
  constructor
  · -- Transitivity to connect (x+1)/2 with (y+9)/(-11)
    linarith [h_eq1, h_eq2]
  · -- Direct from h_eq2
    linarith [h_eq2]

soln_description:
7. (1) Since $\lambda>0$, and $f(1)=f(2)=1, g(1)=g(2)=2, \frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}=\lambda \frac{f(n)}{f(n-1)}, \frac{g(n+1)}{g(n)} \geqslant \lambda \frac{g(n)}{g(n-1)}$, it is easy to see that $f(n)>0, g(n)>0$. From $\frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}=\lambda \frac{f(n)}{f(n-1)}$, we can get
$$
\frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}=\frac{f(2)}{f(1)} \lambda^{n-1}=\lambda^{n-1},
$$

Similarly, from $\frac{g(n+1)}{g(n)} \geqslant \lambda \frac{g(n)}{g(n-1)}$, we can get
$$
\frac{g(n+1)}{g(n)} \geqslant \frac{g(2)}{g(1)} \lambda^{n-1}=\lambda^{n-1}.
$$

Therefore,
$$
\frac{g(n+1)}{g(n)} \geqslant \frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right). \text{ So } \frac{g(n+1)}{f(n+1)} \geqslant \frac{g(n)}{f(n)}.
$$
(2) From $\frac{g(n+1)}{f(n+1)} \geqslant \frac{g(n)}{f(n)}$, we can get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{g(n+1)-f(n+1)}{f(n+1)} \geqslant \frac{g(n)-f(n)}{f(n)} \\
\frac{g(n+1)}{f(n+1)} \geqslant \frac{g(1)}{f(1)}=2,
\end{array}
$$

So $k(n+1) \geqslant 2 f(n+1)>f(n+1)$, thus $g(n+1)-f(n+1)>0$, which means
$$
\frac{g(n)-f(n)}{g(n+1)-f(n+1)} \leqslant \frac{f(n)}{f(n+1)}=\frac{1}{\lambda^{n-1}},
$$

Therefore, $\frac{g(1)-f(1)}{g(2)-f(2)}+\frac{g(2)-f(2)}{g(3)-f(3)}+\cdots+\frac{g(n)-f(n)}{g(n+1)-f(n+1)}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\leqslant 1+\frac{1}{\lambda}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\lambda^{n-1}}=\frac{1-\frac{1}{\lambda^{n}}}{1-\frac{1}{\lambda}} \\
=\frac{\lambda}{\lambda-1}\left(1-\frac{1}{\lambda^{n}}\right).
\end{array}
$$

Since $\lambda>1$, we have
$$
\frac{g(1)-f(1)}{g(2)-f(2)}+\frac{g(2)-f(2)}{g(3)-f(3)}+\cdots+\frac{g(n)-f(n)}{g(n+1)-f(n+1)} < \frac{\lambda}{\lambda-1} \left(1 - \frac{1}{\lambda^n}\right) \left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}, \lambda > 1\right),
$$

If $f(n)$ is a geometric sequence with the first term $f(1)$ and common ratio $q$ ($0 < q \leq 1$), then $f(n) \leqslant f(1) q^{n-1}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}\right)$. This type of geometric inequality problem has appeared multiple times in college entrance exams.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. (2006 Tianjin College Entrance Examination for Science) Given $\{f(n)\},\{g(n)\}$ satisfy $f(1)=f(2)=1, g(1)=$ $g(2)=2$, and $\frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}=\lambda \frac{f(n)}{f(n-1)}, \frac{g(n+1)}{g(n)} \geqslant \lambda \frac{g(n)}{g(n-1)}$ ($\lambda$ is a non-zero parameter, $n=2,3,4, \cdots$).
(1) When $\lambda>0$, prove: $\frac{g(n+1)}{f(n+1)} \geqslant \frac{g(n)}{f(n)}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{+}\right)$;
(2) When $\lambda>1$, prove: $\frac{g(1)-f(1)}{g(2)-f(2)}+\frac{g(2)-f(2)}{g(3)-f(3)}+\cdots+\frac{g(n)-f(n)}{g(n+1)-f(n+1)}<\frac{\lambda}{\lambda-1}$ $\left(n \in \mathbf{N}^{+}\right)$. -/
theorem algebra_226124 {f g : ℕ → ℝ} (hf1 : f 1 = 1) (hf2 : f 2 = 1)
    (hg1 : g 1 = 2) (hg2 : g 2 = 2) (hfn : ∀ n ≥ 2, f (n + 1) / f n = lambda * f n / f (n - 1))
    (hgn : ∀ n ≥ 2, g (n + 1) / g n ≥ lambda * g n / g (n - 1)) :
    (lambda > 0 → ∀ n ≥ 1, g (n + 1) / f (n + 1) ≥ g n / f n) ∧
    (lambda > 1 → ∀ n ≥ 1, ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, (g i - f i) / (g (i + 1) - f (i + 1)) < lambda / (lambda - 1)) := by

soln_description:
6. Prove that if $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are all acute angles, then
$$
0 < \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha} < 1, \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta} < 1, \frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma} < 1 \text {. }
$$

Make the trigonometric substitution $x=\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}, y=\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta}, z=\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}$.
Then the condition simplifies to $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=\cos ^{2} \alpha+\cos ^{2} \beta+\cos ^{2} \gamma=2$, i.e., $\sin ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \beta+\sin ^{2} \gamma=1$.
The inequality to be proved transforms into
$$
\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}} \geqslant \sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}-1}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta}-1}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}-1},
$$

i.e., $\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}} \geqslant \frac{\sin \alpha}{\cos \alpha}+\frac{\sin \beta}{\cos \beta}+\frac{\sin \gamma}{\cos \gamma}$.
Noting equation (1), applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to equation (2) yields
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\sin \alpha}{\cos \alpha}+\frac{\sin \beta}{\cos \beta}+\frac{\sin \gamma}{\cos \gamma} & \leqslant \sqrt{\sin ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \beta+\sin ^{2} \gamma} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}} \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \beta}+\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} \gamma}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Equality in equation (3) holds if and only if $\sin \alpha \cdot \cos \alpha=\sin \beta \cdot \cos \beta=\sin \gamma \cdot \cos \gamma$, i.e., $\alpha=\beta=\gamma$. Therefore, equation (2) holds. Hence, the original inequality is proved.
Note: This problem can also be solved by making the trigonometric substitution $x=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}, y=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \beta}, z=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \gamma}$.
informal_statement:
6. (33rd IMO Preliminary Problem) If $x, y, z>1$, and $\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y}+\frac{1}{z}=2$. Prove: $\sqrt{x+y+z}$
$$
\geqslant \sqrt{x-1}+\sqrt{y-1}+\sqrt{z-1}
$$

$$
\geqslant \sqrt{x-1}+\sqrt{y-1}+\sqrt{z-1}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_151647 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 1 < x) (hy : 1 < y) (hz : 1 < z)
    (h : 1 / x + 1 / y + 1 / z = 2) :
    Real.sqrt (x + y + z) ≥ Real.sqrt (x - 1) + Real.sqrt (y - 1) + Real.sqrt (z - 1) :=

/- Let $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}^+$ such that $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 1$. Prove that $\frac{a}{b^2 + c^2} + \frac{b}{a^2 + c^2} + \frac{c}{a^2 + b^2} \ge \frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}$. -/
theorem inequalities_7514 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
(h : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 1) :
3*sqrt 3 / 2 ≤ a/(b^2+c^2) + b/(a^2+c^2) + c/(a^2+b^2) := by

soln_description:
Solution: From $A B-B A=A$ we obtain $\operatorname{tr}(A)=0$ and $A^{2}=-\Delta \cdot I_{2}$, where $\Delta=\operatorname{det}(A)$....

$A B-B A=A \Rightarrow A B A-B A^{2}=A^{2}$, so $A B A=B A^{2}+A^{2}=-\Delta \cdot B-\Delta \cdot I_{2}$.

$A B-B A=A \Rightarrow A^{2} B-A B A=A^{2}$, so $A B A=A^{2} B-A^{2}=-\Delta \cdot B+\Delta \cdot I_{2}$.

Therefore $\Delta=0$, so $A^{2}=O_{2}=A B A$.

The statement is proved by induction on $n$.

We have proved that $A B^{1} A=O_{2}$, so $P(1)$ is a true statement.

Let $k \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$. Suppose that $A B^{k} A=O_{2}$ and prove that $A B^{k+1} A=O_{2}$. $1 \mathrm{p}$

$A B-B A=A\left|\cdot B^{k} \quad \Rightarrow \quad A B^{k+1}-B A B^{k}=A B^{k}\right| \cdot A, \quad \Rightarrow \quad A B^{k+1} A-B A B^{k} A=A B^{k} A$ $2 \mathrm{p}$ $\stackrel{\text { ind hyp }}{\Leftrightarrow} A B^{k+1} A-B(\underbrace{A B^{k} A}_{O_{2}})=O_{2} \Leftrightarrow \quad A B^{k+1} A=O_{2} \quad$ and by the first principle of induction the conclusion follows $1 \mathrm{p}$
informal_statement:
1. Let $A$ and $B$ be two square matrices of order two with complex elements such that

$A B - B A = A$. Show that $A B^{n} A = O_{2}$, for any $n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$.

G.M. $11 / 2012$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let $A$ and $B$ be two square matrices of order two with complex elements such that

$A B - B A = A$. Show that $A B^{n} A = O_{2}$, for any $n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$.

G.M. $11 / 2012$ -/
theorem algebra_110943 {A B : Matrix (Fin 2) (Fin 2) ℂ} (h : A * B - B * A = A) (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    A * B ^ n * A = 0 := by

soln_description:
1. **Assume the contrary**: Suppose $n+1$ is not a power of $2$ and $n \neq 5$. Let $n = \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_i^{a_i}$ and $n+1 = \prod_{i=1}^{l} q_i^{b_i}$ where $p_1 < p_2 < \cdots < p_k$ and $q_1 < q_2 < \cdots < q_l$ are prime numbers.

2. **Euler's Totient Function**: Recall that $\varphi(n) = n \prod_{p \mid n} \left(1 - \frac{1}{p}\right)$. Given that $\varphi(n)$ and $\varphi(n+1)$ are both powers of $2$, we have:
   \[
   \varphi(n) = \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_i^{a_i-1} \prod_{i=1}^{k} (p_i - 1)
   \]
   \[
   \varphi(n+1) = \prod_{i=1}^{l} q_i^{b_i-1} \prod_{i=1}^{l} (q_i - 1)
   \]

3. **Prime Exponents**: Since $\varphi(n)$ and $\varphi(n+1)$ are powers of $2$, it follows that $a_1 = a_2 = \cdots = a_k = 1$ and $b_2 = b_3 = \cdots = b_l = 1$. This implies that $n$ and $n+1$ are products of distinct primes of the form $2^t + 1$ for some $t \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

4. **Distinct Primes**: The primes $p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_k, q_2, q_3, \ldots, q_l$ must be pairwise distinct since $\gcd(n, n+1) = 1$. These primes are Fermat numbers, which are of the form $2^{2^m} + 1$.

5. **Equation Setup**: We have:
   \[
   \left( \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_i \right) + 1 = n + 1 = 2^{b_1} \prod_{i=2}^{l} q_i
   \]

6. **Case Analysis**:
   - **Case 1**: Suppose $q_l > p_k$. Let $q_l = 2^{2^w} + 1$. Then:
     \[
     \text{LHS} > q_l = 2^{2^w} + 1 = \left( \prod_{i=1}^{w-1} (2^{2^i} + 1) \right) + 2 > \left( \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_i \right) + 1
     \]
     This leads to a contradiction.

   - **Case 2**: Suppose $p_k > q_l$. Let $p_k = 2^{2^v} + 1$.
     - If $k = 1$, then:
       \[
       p_1 + 1 = 2^{b_1} \prod_{i=2}^{l} q_i = \left( \prod_{i=1}^{v-1} (2^{2^i} + 1) \right) + 3
       \]
       Thus, $\prod_{i=2}^{l} q_i \mid 3 \Rightarrow l = 2, q_2 = 3$. Therefore:
       \[
       p_1 = 3 \times 2^{b_1} - 1 \Rightarrow 2^{2^v} = 3 \times 2^{b_1} - 2
       \]
       If $b_1 = 1$, then $2^v = 2$ and so $n = 5$, which is a contradiction. If $b_1 = 1$, it gives $2^{2^v} = 0$, which is impossible.

     - If $k \geq 2$, consider two sub-cases:
       - If $2^{b_1} < p_k$, then $p_k \equiv 1 \pmod{2^{b_1}}$. Thus:
         \[
         \left( \prod_{i=1}^{k-1} p_i \right) + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{2^{b_1}}
         \]
       - If $2^{b_1} \geq p_k$, then:
         \[
         \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_i \equiv -1 \pmod{2^{b_1}}
         \]
         Let $2^{2^z} \leq 2^{b_1} \leq 2^{2^{z+1} - 1}$. Both cases imply that there exist Fermat numbers $w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_h$ all less than $2^{b_1}$ such that:
         \[
         w_1 w_2 \cdots w_h + 1 \equiv F_1 F_2 \cdots F_{z-1} + 1 \pmod{2^{2^z}}
         \]
         Thus:
         \[
         \frac{F_1 F_2 \cdots F_{z-1}}{w_1 w_2 \cdots w_h} \equiv 1 \pmod{2^{2^z} = F_1 F_2 \cdots F_{z-1} - 1}
         \]
         This implies $\{ w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_h \} = \{ F_1, F_2, \ldots, F_{z-1} \}$.

         - If $2^{b_1} \geq p_k$, then $h = k$ and:
           \[
           1 + \prod_{i=1}^{k} p_i = 2^{2^z} < 2^{b_1} \prod_{i=2}^{l} q_i
           \]
           This leads to a contradiction.

         - If $2^{2^z} < 2^{b_1} < p_k$, then $p_1 = F_1, p_2 = F_2, \ldots, p_{k-1} = F_{z-1}$. Thus:
           \[
           p_k (2^{2^z} - 1) + 1 = 2^{b_1} \prod_{i=2}^{l} q_i
           \]
           Therefore, $q_2, q_3, \ldots, q_l \geq 2^{2^z} + 1$, so:
           \[
           p_k (2^{2^z} - 1) < \text{LHS} = \text{RHS} < (2^{2^{z+1} - 1}) \frac{p_k}{F_1 F_2 \cdots F_{z-1} = 2^{2^z} - 1}
           \]
           This implies:
           \[
           (2^{2^z} - 1)^2 \leq 2^{2^{z+1} - 1}
           \]
           which is false for all $z \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

7. **Conclusion**: Since all cases lead to contradictions, the only possibilities are that $n+1$ is a power of $2$ or $n = 5$.

$\blacksquare$
informal_statement: Let $n$ be an odd positive integer such that $\varphi (n)$ and $\varphi (n+1)$ are both powers of $2$ (here $\varphi(n)$ denotes Euler’s totient function). Prove that $n+1$ is a power of $2$ or $n = 5$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $n$ be an odd positive integer such that $\varphi (n)$ and $\varphi (n+1)$ are both powers of $2$ (here $\varphi(n)$ denotes Euler’s totient function). Prove that $n+1$ is a power of $2$ or $n = 5$. -/
theorem number_theory_49056 {n : ℕ} (hn : Odd n ∧ n > 0)
    (hφ : ∃ k, Nat.totient n = 2 ^ k) (hφ' : ∃ m, Nat.totient (n + 1) = 2 ^ m) :
    ∃ p, n + 1 = 2 ^ p ∨ n = 5 := by

soln_description:
65. Answer: 4.

For example, consider the polynomial $P(x)=(x-3)(x-1)(x+1)(x+3)$. It is even. Therefore, if $c \neq P(0)$, then $l_{P}(c)$ is even. Therefore, in $A$ there can only be one odd number, namely, $l_{P}(P(0))$. Thus, $b=1$ or $b=3$ is the desired number, since $0,4 \in A_{P}$. Why can't the degree be less? Consider, for example, a cubic polynomial $P$. Since its derivative is a quadratic polynomial, it has no more than two roots, and thus $P$ has no more than three intervals of monotonicity, specifically 1 or 3. Let's consider the most complex case immediately - when $P$ has three intervals of monotonicity. Suppose it has a local minimum $m$ and a local maximum $M$. Then for $x \in(-\infty, m) \cup(M,+\infty)$, $l_{P}(x)=1$, $l_{P}(m)=l_{P}(M)=2$, and for $x \in(m, M)$, $l_{P}(x)=3$. The other cases are even simpler to analyze.
informal_statement: 65. What is the smallest degree that a polynomial $P$ can have if it is known that there exists an integer $b$ such that $A_{P}$ contains elements both greater and smaller than $b$, but does not contain $b$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 65. What is the smallest degree that a polynomial $P$ can have if it is known that there exists an integer $b$ such that $A_{P}$ contains elements both greater and smaller than $b$, but does not contain $b$? -/
theorem algebra_219482 {A : Polynomial ℤ → Set ℤ} (hA : ∀ P, A P = {x | x > 0 ∨ x < 0}) :
    IsLeast {n | ∃ P, P.degree = n ∧ ∃ b, {x | x > b} ⊆ A P ∧ {x | x < b} ⊆ A P ∧ b ∉ A P} 4 := by

soln_description:
We first observe some initial values, and it is easy to calculate that the first few terms are
$$
1,2,7,29,22,23,49,26,-17,-163, \cdots \text {. }
$$

None of these are equal to zero, and none of them are multiples of 4. We then divide these numbers by 4 and examine the remainders. We get $1,2,3,1,2,3,1,2,3,1, \cdots$.
Thus, we conjecture that for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
a_{3 n-2} \equiv 1(\bmod 4), a_{3 n-1} \equiv 2(\bmod 4), a_{3 n} \equiv 3(\bmod 4) .
$$

We will prove this by mathematical induction.
For $n=1$, it is clear that $a_{1} \equiv 1(\bmod 4), a_{2} \equiv 2(\bmod 4), a_{3} \equiv 7 \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$.
Assume that for $n=k$, we have $a_{3 k-2} \equiv 1(\bmod 4), a_{3 k-1} \equiv 2(\bmod 4), a_{3 k} \equiv 3(\bmod 4)$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{3(k+1)-2}=a_{3 k+1}=5 a_{3 k}-3 a_{3 k-1} \equiv 15-6(\bmod 4) \equiv 1(\bmod 4), \\
a_{3(k+1)-1}=a_{3 k+2}=a_{3 k+1}-a_{3 k} \equiv 1-3(\bmod 4)=2(\bmod 4), \\
a_{3(k+1)}=a_{3 k+3}=5 a_{3 k+2}-3 a_{3 k+1} \equiv 10-3(\bmod 4) \equiv 3(\bmod 4),
\end{array}
$$

Thus, the conjecture is also true for $n=k+1$.
Therefore, the conjecture is true for all positive integers $n$. Hence, $a_{n}, n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}$ are not multiples of 4, and of course $a_{n} \neq 0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3.3.9 ** Given $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=2$, for $n \geqslant 3$,
$$
a_{n}=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
5 a_{n-1}-3 a_{n-2}, & \text { if } a_{n-2} a_{n-1} \text { is even, } \\
a_{n-1}-a_{n-2}, & \text { if } a_{n-2} a_{n-1}
\end{array}\right. \text { is odd. }
$$

Prove: For all positive integers $n$, $a_{n} \neq 0$. -/
theorem algebra_100200 (a : ℕ → ℤ)
    (h₀ : a 1 = 1)
    (h₁ : a 2 = 2)
    (h₂ : ∀ n ≥ 3, a n = if Even (a (n - 2) * a (n - 1)) then 5 * a (n - 1) - 3 * a (n - 2) else a (n - 1) - a (n - 2)) :
    ∀ n > 0, a n ≠ 0 := by

soln_description:
Notice,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
12+2 \mathrm{e}^{0.4 \pi \mathrm{i}}+\mathrm{e}^{1.2 \pi \mathrm{i}} \\
=\sqrt{\left(2+2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{5}+\cos \frac{6 \pi}{5}\right)^{2}+\left(2 \sin \frac{2 \pi}{5}+\sin \frac{6 \pi}{5}\right)^{2}} \\
=\sqrt{9+8 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{5}+4 \cos \frac{6 \pi}{5}+4 \cos \frac{4 \pi}{5}} \\
=\sqrt{9+8 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{5}-8 \cos \frac{\pi}{5}} \\
=\sqrt{9-16 \sin \frac{3 \pi}{10} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{10}} \\
=\sqrt{9-16 \cos 36^{\circ} \cdot \cos 72^{\circ}} \\
=\sqrt{9-\frac{16 \cos 36^{\circ} \cdot \cos 72^{\circ} \cdot \sin 36^{\circ}}{\sin 36^{\circ}}} \\
=\sqrt{9-\frac{4 \sin 144^{\circ}}{\sin 36^{\circ}}}=\sqrt{5} .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
Example 6 Find the modulus of $2+2 e^{0.4 \pi i}+e^{1.2 \pi i}$.
(2009, Tsinghua University Independent Recruitment Examination)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Find the modulus of $2+2 e^{0.4 \pi i}+e^{1.2 \pi i}$.
(2009, Tsinghua University Independent Recruitment Examination) -/
theorem algebra_325556 : ‖2 + 2 * Complex.exp (Complex.I * 0.4 * Real.pi) + Complex.exp (Complex.I * 1.2 * Real.pi)‖ = Real.sqrt 5 := by

soln_description:
Eight, Solution: The original equation is rearranged as
$$
(\mathrm{k}+5) \mathrm{x}^{2}-(2 \mathrm{k}-5) \mathrm{x}+12=0 \text {. }
$$

Let the two roots of the equation be $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}+x_{2}=\frac{2 k-5}{k+5}, \\
x_{1} \cdot x_{2}=\frac{12}{k+5} .
\end{array}
$$

Since $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ are the cosines of the two acute angles of a right triangle, let $x_{1}=\cos \mathrm{A}, \mathrm{x}_{2}=\cos \mathrm{B}=\sin \mathrm{A}$, then
$$
x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}=\cos ^{2} A+\sin ^{2} A=1,
$$

which means $\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)^{2}-2 x_{1} x_{2}=1$;
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\therefore\left(\frac{2 k-5}{k+5}\right)^{2}-\frac{24}{k+5}=1, \\
(2 k-5)^{2}-24(k+5)=(k+5)^{2},
\end{array}
$$

Rearranging gives $\mathrm{k}^{2}-18 \mathrm{k}-40=0$,
$$
\therefore \mathrm{k}_{1}=-2, \mathrm{k}_{2}=20 \text {. }
$$
Since $\mathrm{x}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{x}_{2}$ are the cosines of two acute angles,
$$
\therefore \mathrm{x}_{1}>0, \quad \mathrm{x}_{2}>0 \text {. }
$$

But when $k=-2$, the original equation becomes $x^{2}+3 x+4=0$,
$$
\therefore x_{1}+x_{2}=-3 \text { and } x_{2}>0 \text {, which is a contradiction. }
$$

Therefore, $\mathrm{k}=-2$ does not meet the requirements and is discarded.
Finally, $\mathrm{k}=20$.
informal_statement:
Eight. For what value of $\mathrm{k}$, the roots of the equation $3\left(\mathrm{x}^{2}+3 \mathrm{x}+4\right)$ $=x(2-x)(2+k)$ are the sides of a right triangle

保持了源文本的换行和格式。
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Eight. For what value of $\mathrm{k}$ will the roots of the equation $3\left(\mathrm{x}^{2}+3 \mathrm{x}+4\right)$ $=x(2-x)(2+k)$ be the legs of a right triangle? -/
theorem algebra_297266 (k : ℝ) (h : ∃ x y z, x ≠ y ∧ y ≠ z ∧ z ≠ x ∧
    3*(x^2+3*x+4) = x*(2-x)*(2+k) ∧ 3*(y^2+3*y+4) = y*(2-y)*(2+k) ∧
    3*(z^2+3*z+4) = z*(2-z)*(2+k) ∧ x^2+y^2 = z^2) :
    k = 20 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_297266 (k : ℝ) (h : ∃ x y z, x ≠ y ∧ y ≠ z ∧ z ≠ x ∧
    3*(x^2+3*x+4) = x*(2-x)*(2+k) ∧ 3*(y^2+3*y+4) = y*(2-y)*(2+k) ∧
    3*(z^2+3*z+4) = z*(2-z)*(2+k) ∧ x^2+y^2 = z^2) :
    k = 20 := by
  rcases h with ⟨x, y, z, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, h7⟩
  have eq1 : (k + 5) * x^2 + (5 - 2 * k) * x + 12 = 0 := by
    nlinarith
  have eq2 : (k + 5) * y^2 + (5 - 2 * k) * y + 12 = 0 := by
      nlinarith
  have eq3 : (k + 5) * z^2 + (5 - 2 * k) * z + 12 = 0 := by
      nlinarith
  have eq4 : (k + 5) * (x^2 - y^2) + (5 - 2 * k) * (x - y) = 0 := by 
    nlinarith [eq1, eq2]
  have eq5 : (x - y) * ( (k + 5) * (x + y) + (5 - 2 * k) ) = 0 := by
    ring_nf at eq4 ⊢
    <;> nlinarith
  cases (mul_eq_zero.mp eq5) with
  | inl h8 =>
    exfalso
    exact h1 (by linarith)
  | inr h9 =>
    have eq6 : (k + 5) * (x^2 - z^2) + (5 - 2 * k) * (x - z) = 0 := by 
      nlinarith [eq1, eq3]
    have eq7 : (x - z) * ( (k + 5) * (x + z) + (5 - 2 * k) ) = 0 := by
      ring_nf at eq6 ⊢
      <;> nlinarith
    cases (mul_eq_zero.mp eq7) with
    | inl h10 =>
      exfalso
      have h12 : z = x := by linarith
      have h13 : z = x := by linarith
      exfalso
      exact h3 (by linarith)
    | inr h11 =>
      have eq8 : (k + 5) * (y^2 - z^2) + (5 - 2 * k) * (y - z) = 0 := by 
        nlinarith [eq2, eq3]
      have eq9 : (y - z) * ( (k + 5) * (y + z) + (5 - 2 * k) ) = 0 := by
        ring_nf at eq8 ⊢
        <;> nlinarith
      cases (mul_eq_zero.mp eq9) with
      | inl h14 =>
        exfalso
        have h15 : y = z := by linarith
        exfalso
        exact h2 (by linarith)
      | inr h17 =>
        have eq10 : (k + 5) * (y - z) = 0 := by
          nlinarith [h9, h11, h17]
        have hk : k + 5 = 0 := by
          apply_fun (fun w => w / (y - z)) at eq10
          field_simp [(show y - z ≠ 0 by intro h'; apply h2; linarith)] at eq10
          linarith
        have h18 : k = -5 := by linarith
        have h19 : 5 - 2 * k = 0 := by
          rw [hk] at h9
          nlinarith
        linarith [h18, h19]
