soln_description:
Prove $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+12 a b c \leqslant \sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} a^{2} \sqrt{a^{2}+24 b c}$
$$\Leftrightarrow \sum_{\mathrm{cyc}}\left(a^{3} b^{3}+24 a^{2} b^{2} c^{2}\right) \leqslant \sum_{\mathrm{cyc}} a^{2} b^{2} \sqrt{\left(a^{2}+24 b c\right)\left(b^{2}+24 a c\right)} .$$

Since
$$\sqrt{\left(a^{2}+24 b c\right)\left(b^{2}+24 a c\right)} \geqslant a b+24 c \sqrt{a b}$$

It suffices to prove
$$\sum_{\mathrm{cyc}}(a b \sqrt{a b}-a b c) \geqslant 0$$

By Muirhead's theorem, the above inequality is obviously true, hence the original inequality holds.
informal_statement:
Example 29 Prove: For non-negative real numbers $a, b, c$, we have
$$a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+12 a b c \leqslant \sum a^{2} \sqrt{a^{2}+24 b c} .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 29 Prove: For non-negative real numbers $a, b, c$, we have
$$a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}+12 a b c \leqslant \sum a^{2} \sqrt{a^{2}+24 b c} .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_601642 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hb : 0 ≤ b) (hc : 0 ≤ c) :
    a^3 + b^3 + c^3 + 12 * a * b * c ≤ a^2 * sqrt (a^2 + 24 * b * c) +
      b^2 * sqrt (b^2 + 24 * c * a) + c^2 * sqrt (c^2 + 24 * a * b) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

The area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$ is numerically equal to the modulus of their vector product:

$S=|a \times b|$

We compute $a \times b$ using the properties of the vector product:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a \times b=(4 p+q) \times(p-q)=4 \cdot p \times p-4 \cdot p \times q+q \times p-q \times q= \\
& =-4 \cdot p \times q+q \times p=-4 \cdot p \times q-p \times q=(-4-1) \cdot p \times q=-5 \cdot p \times q
\end{aligned}
$$

We compute the area:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S=|a \times b|=|-5 \cdot p \times q|=5 \cdot|p \times q|=5 \cdot|p| \cdot|q| \cdot \sin (\widehat{p, q})= \\
& =5 \cdot 7 \cdot 2 \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{4}=70 \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{4}=70 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=35 \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$ is $35 \sqrt{2}$.

## Problem Kuznetsov Analytic Geometry 5-8
informal_statement:
## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$.

$a=4 p+q$

$b=p-q$

$|p|=7$

$|q|=2$

$(\widehat{p, q})=\frac{\pi}{4}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task Condition

Calculate the area of the parallelogram constructed on vectors $a$ and $b$.

$a=4 p+q$

$b=p-q$

$|p|=7$

$|q|=2$

$(\widehat{p, q})=\frac{\pi}{4}$ -/
theorem algebra_135743 {a b p q : ℝ × ℝ}
    (ha : a = 4 * p + q) (hb : b = p - q)
    (hp : ‖p‖ = 7) (hq : ‖q‖ = 2)
    (h : Real.pi / 4 = Real.arccos ((p.1 * q.1 + p.2 * q.2) / (‖p‖ * ‖q‖))) :
    ‖a.1 * b.2 - a.2 * b.1‖ = 35 * Real.sqrt 2 := by

soln_description:
Answer: $\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$.

Solution. By the inequality for the harmonic mean and the arithmetic mean

$$
\frac{1}{\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{x_{1}}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{x_{n}}}} \leqslant \frac{\sqrt[4]{x_{1}}+\ldots+\sqrt[4]{x_{n}}}{n^{2}}
$$

Note that for any $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}$

$$
\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}\right)^{4} \leqslant\left(n \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant n^{3} \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}^{4}
$$

From here, by the Cauchy inequality

$$
A^{2} \leqslant \frac{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sqrt[4]{1-x_{k}}\right)^{2} \cdot\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sqrt[4]{x_{k}}\right)^{2}}{n^{4}} \leqslant \frac{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sqrt[4]{1-x_{k}}\right)^{4}+\left(\sum_{k=1}^{n} \sqrt[4]{x_{k}}\right)^{4}}{2 n^{4}} \leqslant \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(1-x_{k}\right)+\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}}{2 n}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

Therefore, $A \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$. Equality is achieved when $x_{1}=\ldots=x_{n}=\frac{1}{2}$.
informal_statement:
3. Given numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in(0,1)$. Find the maximum value of the expression

$$
A=\frac{\sqrt[4]{1-x_{1}}+\ldots+\sqrt[4]{1-x_{n}}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{x_{1}}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{x_{n}}}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 3. Given numbers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in(0,1)$. Find the maximum value of the expression

$$
A=\frac{\sqrt[4]{1-x_{1}}+\ldots+\sqrt[4]{1-x_{n}}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{x_{1}}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{\sqrt[4]{x_{n}}}}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_220472 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n → ℝ)
  (hx : ∀ i, 0 < x i ∧ x i < 1) :
  IsGreatest {a | ∃ x : Fin n → ℝ, (∀ i, 0 < x i ∧ x i < 1) ∧
    a = (∑ i, (1 - x i) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 4)) / (∑ i, 1 / (x i) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 4))} (Real.sqrt 2 / 2) := by

soln_description:
Prove that
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(1+x)^{n p} \\
=\left(1+\mathrm{C}_{p}^{1} x+\mathrm{C}_{p}^{2} x^{2}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{p}^{p-1} x^{p-1}+x^{p}\right)^{n} .
\end{array}
$$

By comparing the coefficients of \( x^p \) on both sides, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{C}_{n p}^{p} \equiv & n+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2} \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{p-i}+ \\
& \mathrm{C}_{n}^{3} \sum_{\substack{i, j, k>1 \\
i+j+k=p}} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{j} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{k}\left(\bmod p^{4}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since \( p > 3 \) and \( p \mid (n-1) \), it follows that \( p \mid \mathrm{C}_{n}^{3} \).
Also, \( p \mid \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i} \) for \( i = 1, 2, \cdots, p-1 \), thus
\[
\mathrm{C}_{n p}^{p} - n \equiv \mathrm{C}_{n}^{2} \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{p-i} \left(\bmod p^{4}\right).
\]
We need to prove that:
\[
\sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{p-i} \equiv 0 \left(\bmod p^{3}\right).
\]
This is because
\[
\frac{1}{p^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{p-i} = \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \left(\frac{1}{p} \mathrm{C}_{p}^{i}\right)^{2}
\]
\[
= \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \left(\frac{(p-1)(p-2) \cdots (p-i+1)}{i!}\right)^{2}
\]
\[
\equiv \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \frac{1^{2} \cdot 2^{2} \cdots (i-1)^{2}}{(i!)^{2}} \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \frac{1}{i^{2}}
\]
\[
\equiv \sum_{i=1}^{p-1} i^{2} \left(\bar{i} \text{ is the inverse of } i \text{ modulo } p\right)
\]
\[
= \sum_{j=1}^{p-1} j^{2} \left(\text{as } i \text{ runs through the reduced residue system modulo } p, \text{ so does } \bar{i}\right)
\]
\[
= \frac{(p-1) p (2 p-1)}{6} \equiv 0 \left(\bmod p\right).
\]
Clearly, \( p \mid \mathrm{C}_{n}^{2} \).
Thus,
\[
\mathrm{C}_{n p}^{p} - n \equiv 0 \left(\bmod p^{4}\right).
\]
The proposition is proved.
informal_statement: Let $p$ be a prime greater than 3, $n$ be a positive integer, and $n \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. Prove: $p^{4} \mid \left(\mathrm{C}_{n p}^{p}-n\right)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $p$ be a prime greater than 3, $n$ be a positive integer, and $n \equiv 1(\bmod p)$. Prove: $p^{4} \mid \left(\mathrm{C}_{n p}^{p}-n\right)$. -/
theorem number_theory_99207 (p n : ℕ) (hp : Nat.Prime p) (hn : 0 < n)
    (hpn : n ≡ 1 [MOD p]) (h : 3 < p) :
    p^4 ∣ Nat.choose (n * p) p - n := by

soln_description:
Let $A \rightarrow 0, B \rightarrow \pi, C \rightarrow 0 \Rightarrow 3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C \rightarrow 6$;
Let $\cos A \rightarrow -\frac{3}{8}, \cos B \rightarrow \frac{3}{8}, C \rightarrow 0$ when, $\cos 2B = 2 \times \frac{9}{64} - 1 = -\frac{23}{32}$, then $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C \rightarrow -\frac{9}{8} - \frac{23}{16} + 1 = -\frac{25}{16}$.
Clearly, $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C - \frac{25}{16}$. If $A \leqslant \frac{\pi}{3}$, then $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C \geqslant \frac{3}{2} - 2 - 1 = -\frac{3}{2} > -\frac{25}{16}$;
If $B \leqslant C$, then $A + 2B \leqslant A + B + C = \pi \Rightarrow A \leqslant \pi - 2B \Rightarrow \cos A + \cos 2B \geqslant 0$, $A + C - \cos C$,
Thus, $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C \geqslant \cos A + \cos 3C > \cos 3C - \cos C$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
= -2 \sin 2C \sin C = -4 \sin^2 C \cos C = -2 \sqrt{2} \cdot \sqrt{\sin^2 C \cdot \sin^2 C \cdot (2 - 2 \sin^2 C)} \\
\geqslant -2 \sqrt{2} \cdot \sqrt{\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^3} = -\frac{8}{3 \sqrt{3}} > -\frac{25}{16} ;
\end{array}
$$

If $A > \frac{\pi}{3}$, and $B > C$, since $\cos A + \cos B = 2 \cos \frac{A+B}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{A-B}{2}$,
$$
\cos (A + B - C) + \cos C = 2 \cos \frac{A+B}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{A+B-2C}{2},
$$

then $\cos \frac{A-B}{2} > \cos \frac{A+B-2C}{2} \Rightarrow \cos A + \cos B > \cos (A + B - C) + \cos C$.
Thus, $3(\cos A + \cos B) + \cos 3C > 3[\cos (A + B - C) + \cos C] + \cos 3C$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
= 3[\cos (\pi - 2C) + \cos C] + 4 \cos^3 C - 3 \cos C = -3 \cos 2C + 4 \cos^3 C \\
= -3(2 \cos^2 C - 1) + 4 \cos^3 C = 1 + 2(2 \cos^3 C - 3 \cos^2 C + 1) \\
= 1 + 2(2 \cos C + 1)(\cos C - 1)^2 > 1 \Rightarrow 3 \cos A + \cos 3C > 1 - 3 \cos B .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C > 2 \cos 2B - 3 \cos B + 1 = 4 \cos^2 B - 3 \cos B - 1$
$$
= 4\left(\cos B - \frac{3}{8}\right)^2 - \frac{25}{16} \geqslant -\frac{25}{16} \text{. }
$$

In summary, the range of $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C$ is $\left(-\frac{25}{16}, 6\right)$.
informal_statement: 8. Let $A, B, C$ be the three interior angles of $\triangle ABC$, then the range of values for $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 8. Let $A, B, C$ be the three interior angles of $\triangle ABC$, then the range of values for $3 \cos A + 2 \cos 2B + \cos 3C$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_168811 (A B C : ℝ) (hA : A ∈ Ioo 0 π)
  (hB : B ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hC : C ∈ Ioo 0 π) (hABC : A + B + C = π) :
  3 * cos A + 2 * cos (2 * B) + cos (3 * C) ∈ Ioo (-25 / 16) 6 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Domain of definition: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x \neq-2, \\ x \neq-1, \\ x \neq 0 .\end{array}\right.$

Bring all terms of the equation to a common denominator:

$$
\frac{6 x^{2}(x+2)+6 x(x+1)^{2}+6(x+1)(x+2)^{2}-25 x(x+1)(x+2)}{6 x(x+1)(x+2)}=0 \Leftrightarrow
$$

$\Leftrightarrow \frac{7 x^{3}+21 x^{2}-4 x-24}{6 x(x+1)(x+2)}=0 \Leftrightarrow 7 x^{3}+21 x^{2}-4 x-24=0$ for $x \neq 0, x \neq-1$, $x \neq-2$. By checking, we find that $x_{1}=1$, since $7+21-4-24=0$. We divide the left side of the equation by $x-1: \frac{7 x^{3}+21 x^{2}-4 x-24}{x-1}=7 x^{2}+28 x+24$, therefore, the original equation can be represented as

$$
(x-1)\left(7 x^{2}+28 x+24\right)=0
$$

Solving the equation $7 x^{2}+28 x+24=0$, we find two more roots: $x_{2}=-2-\frac{2 \sqrt{7}}{7} ; x_{3}=-2+\frac{2 \sqrt{7}}{7}$.

Answer: $x_{1}=1, x_{2,3}=-2 \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{7}}{7}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6.137. $\frac{x}{x+1}+\frac{x+1}{x+2}+\frac{x+2}{x}=\frac{25}{6}$. -/
theorem algebra_165488 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ≠ 0) :
    x / (x + 1) + (x + 1) / (x + 2) + (x + 2) / x = 25 / 6 ↔
    x = 1 ∨ x = -2 * (1 + Real.sqrt 7) / 7 ∨ x = -2 * (1 - Real.sqrt 7) / 7 := by

soln_description:
Proof: Let the left side of the inequality be $M$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
M=(a+b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n} \\
=\mathrm{C}_{n}^{1} a^{n-1} b+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2} a^{n-2} b^{2}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n-1} a b^{n-1} .
\end{array}
$$

Reversing the order of $M$ gives
$$
M=\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n-1} a b^{n-1}+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n-2} a^{2} b^{n-2}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{1} a^{n-1} b \text {. }
$$

Adding the two expressions, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
2 M=\mathrm{C}_{n}^{1}\left(a^{n-1} b+a b^{n-1}\right)+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2}\left(a^{n-2} b^{2}+\right. \\
\left.\quad a^{2} b^{n-2}\right)+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n-1}\left(a b^{n-1}+a^{n-1} b\right) \\
\geqslant 2\left(\mathrm{C}_{n}^{1} \sqrt{a^{n} b^{n}}+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2} \sqrt{a^{n} b^{n}}+\cdots+\right. \\
\\
\left.\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n-1} \sqrt{a^{n} b^{n}}\right) \\
=2 \sqrt{a^{n} b^{n}}\left(\mathrm{C}_{n}^{1}+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{2}+\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{n}^{n-1}\right) \\
=2 \sqrt{a^{n} b^{n}}\left(2^{n}-2\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Since $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=1$, and $a, b$ are positive real numbers, we have
$$
1 \geqslant 2 \sqrt{\frac{1}{a b}}, a b \geqslant 4 \text {. }
$$

Thus, $2 M \geqslant 2 \sqrt{4^{n}}\left(2^{n}-2\right)$,
which implies $M \geqslant 2^{2 n}-2^{n+1}$.
informal_statement:
Example 9 Given that $a, b$ are positive real numbers, and $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=$
1. Prove: For every $n \in \mathbf{N}$, we have
$$
(a+b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n} \geqslant 2^{2 n}-2^{n+1} .
$$
(1988, National High School Mathematics Competition)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 9 Given that $a, b$ are positive real numbers, and $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}=$
1. Prove: For every $n \in \mathbf{N}$, we have
$$
(a+b)^{n}-a^{n}-b^{n} \geqslant 2^{2 n}-2^{n+1} .
$$
(1988, National High School Mathematics Competition) -/
theorem inequalities_302693 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : 1 / a + 1 / b = 1) (n : ℕ) :
    (a + b) ^ n - a ^ n - b ^ n ≥ 2 ^ (2 * n) - 2 ^ (n + 1) := by

soln_description:
Proof: Let $\left(\frac{x}{x-1}\right)^{2}=m,\left(\frac{y}{y-1}\right)^{2}=n$,
$$
\left(\frac{z}{z-1}\right)^{2}=p \text {. }
$$

Then $m+n+p=1$.
Since $x-11$, the condition does not hold), so,
$$
\frac{x}{x-1}=-\sqrt{m} \Rightarrow x=\frac{\sqrt{m}}{1+\sqrt{m}} \text {. }
$$

Similarly, $y=\frac{\sqrt{n}}{1+\sqrt{n}}, z=\frac{\sqrt{p}}{1+\sqrt{p}}$.
Thus, $x+y+z=\frac{\sqrt{m}}{1+\sqrt{m}}+\frac{\sqrt{n}}{1+\sqrt{n}}+\frac{\sqrt{p}}{1+\sqrt{p}}$.
We need to prove $\frac{\sqrt{m}}{1+\sqrt{m}} \geqslant \frac{m}{2}$.
Equation (1) $\Leftrightarrow \frac{\sqrt{m}}{2}(1+\sqrt{m}) \leqslant 1$.
By $\sqrt{m} \leqslant 1$, we know that Equation (1) holds.
Similarly, $\frac{\sqrt{n}}{1+\sqrt{n}} \geqslant \frac{n}{2}, \frac{\sqrt{p}}{1+\sqrt{p}} \geqslant \frac{p}{2}$.
Adding the three inequalities, we get
$$
x+y+z \geqslant \frac{1}{2} m+\frac{1}{2} n+\frac{1}{2} p=\frac{1}{2},
$$

where the equality holds when one of $m, n, p$ is 1 and the other two are 0.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Also, } 3-x-y-z \\
=\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{m}}+\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{n}}+\frac{1}{1+\sqrt{p}} \\
\geqslant \frac{9}{3+\sqrt{m}+\sqrt{n}+\sqrt{p}} \\
\geqslant \frac{9}{3+\sqrt{3(m+n+p)}}=\frac{9}{3+\sqrt{3}} \\
\Rightarrow x+y+z \leqslant 3-\frac{9}{3+\sqrt{3}}=\frac{3}{2}(\sqrt{3}-1) .
\end{array}
$$

The equality holds when $x=y=z=\frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{2}$.
References:
[1] Gan Chaoyi. Discussion on Unconventional Maximum and Minimum Values of Multivariate Symmetric Expressions [J]. Middle School Mathematics, 2009(7).
[2] Gan Chaoyi. Supplement to the Discussion on Unconventional Maximum and Minimum Values of Multivariate Symmetric Expressions [J]. Middle School Mathematics, 2009(11).
[3] Gan Chaoyi. Methods for Finding the Maximum and Minimum Values of Cyclic Symmetric Expressions [J]. Middle School Mathematics, 2011(2).
informal_statement:
Example 5 Let non-negative real numbers $x, y, z$ (all not equal to 1) satisfy
$$
\left(\frac{x}{x-1}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{y}{y-1}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{z}{z-1}\right)^{2}=1 \text {. }
$$

Prove: $\frac{1}{2} \leqslant x+y+z \leqslant \frac{3}{2}(\sqrt{3}-1)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 5 Let non-negative real numbers $x, y, z$ (all not equal to 1) satisfy
$$
\left(\frac{x}{x-1}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{y}{y-1}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{z}{z-1}\right)^{2}=1 \text {. }
$$

Prove: $\frac{1}{2} \leqslant x+y+z \leqslant \frac{3}{2}(\sqrt{3}-1)$. -/
theorem inequalities_325471 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 ≤ x) (hy : 0 ≤ y) (hz : 0 ≤ z)
    (hne : x ≠ 1 ∧ y ≠ 1 ∧ z ≠ 1) (h : (x / (x - 1)) ^ 2 + (y / (y - 1)) ^ 2 + (z / (z - 1)) ^ 2 = 1) :
    1 / 2 ≤ x + y + z ∧ x + y + z ≤ 3 / 2 * (Real.sqrt 3 - 1) := by

informal_statement:
Prove the following inequality.

\[\frac{1}{12}(\pi -6+2\sqrt{3})\leq \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \ln (1+\cos 2x) dx\leq \frac{1}{4}(2-\sqrt{3})\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Prove the following inequality.

\[\frac{1}{12}(\pi -6+2\sqrt{3})\leq \int_{\frac{\pi}{6}}^{\frac{\pi}{4}} \ln (1+\cos 2x) dx\leq \frac{1}{4}(2-\sqrt{3})\] -/
theorem inequalities_26817 :
  (1/12) * (π - 6 + 2*sqrt 3) ≤ ∫ x in (π/6)..(π/4), log (1 + cos (2*x)) ∧
  ∫ x in (π/6)..(π/4), log (1 + cos (2*x)) ≤ (1/4) * (2 - sqrt 3) := by

informal_statement:
The sides of a triangle have lengths $a,b,c$. Prove that:
\begin{align*}(-a+b+c)(a-b+c)\, +\, & (a-b+c)(a+b-c)+(a+b-c)(-a+b+c)\\ &\le\sqrt{abc}(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c})\end{align*}
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- The sides of a triangle have lengths $a,b,c$. Prove that:
\begin{align*}(-a+b+c)(a-b+c)\, +\, & (a-b+c)(a+b-c)+(a+b-c)(-a+b+c)\\ &\le\sqrt{abc}(\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}+\sqrt{c})\end{align*} -/
theorem inequalities_31448 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
  (h : a + b > c) (h' : a + c > b) (h'' : b + c > a) :
  (-a + b + c) * (a - b + c) + (a - b + c) * (a + b - c) +
  (a + b - c) * (-a + b + c) ≤
  sqrt (a * b * c) * (sqrt a + sqrt b + sqrt c) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

theorem inequalities_31448 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
  (h : a + b > c) (h' : a + c > b) (h'' : b + c > a) :
  (-a + b + c) * (a - b + c) + (a - b + c) * (a + b - c) +
  (a + b - c) * (-a + b + c) ≤
  sqrt (a * b * c) * (sqrt a + sqrt b + sqrt c) := by
    have h1 : 0 ≤ sqrt a := Real.sqrt_nonneg a
    have h2 : 0 ≤ sqrt b := Real.sqrt_nonneg b
    have h3 : 0 ≤ sqrt c := Real.sqrt_nonneg c
    have h4 : (sqrt a) ^ 2 = a := Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ≤ a by linarith)
    have h5 : (sqrt b) ^ 2 = b := Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ≤ b by linarith)
    have h6 : (sqrt c) ^ 2 = c := Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ≤ c by linarith)
    have h7 : sqrt (a * b * c) = sqrt a * sqrt b * sqrt c := by
      have h8 : sqrt (a * b * c) = sqrt ((a * b) * c) := by ring_nf
      have h9 : sqrt ((a * b) * c) = sqrt (a * b) * sqrt c := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_mul]
        positivity
      have h10 : sqrt (a * b) = sqrt a * sqrt b := by
        rw [Real.sqrt_mul]
        positivity
      rw [h8, h9, h10]
      all_goals positivity
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (sqrt a - sqrt b), sq_nonneg (sqrt b - sqrt c), sq_nonneg (sqrt c - sqrt a),
      Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ≤ (a : ℝ) by linarith), Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ≤ (b : ℝ) by linarith), Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ≤ (c : ℝ) by linarith),
      mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg a) (Real.sqrt_nonneg b), mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg b) (Real.sqrt_nonneg c), mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg a) (Real.sqrt_nonneg c),
      h, h', h'']

informal_statement: Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? -/
theorem number_theory_23183 : IsGreatest {n : ℕ | ∃ s : Finset ℕ, s.card = n ∧ ∀ x ∈ s, x ∈ Finset.Icc 1 16 ∧ ¬∃ x ∈ s, ∃ y ∈ s, x ≠ y ∧ IsSquare (x * y)} 11 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let $K=\sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{2}}$ and $A=\frac{a+b}{2}$. From the inequality between the arithmetic and quadratic means, we get $K \geq A \geq 1$, so $A^{3} \geq 1, K-A \geq 0$ and $3(K+A) \geq 2(K+2 A)$.

We have,

$$
a b=2 A^{2}-K^{2}, \quad\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right)^{2}=(a+b)^{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}-2 a b\right)=16 A^{2}\left(K^{2}-A^{2}\right)
$$

therefore, inequality (1) can be written in the form

$$
\frac{3}{4} A^{2}\left(A^{2}-K^{2}\right)+\frac{2 A^{2}-K^{2}}{2 A} \geq \frac{K}{2}
$$

i.e., in the equivalent inequality

$$
3 A^{3}(K-A)(K+A) \geq 2(K-A)(K+2 A)
$$

which is clearly satisfied.

## II year
informal_statement:
4. If $a \geq 1, b \geq 1$, then

$$
3\left(\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{8}\right)^{2}+\frac{a b}{a+b} \geq \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{8}}
$$

Prove!
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 4. If $a \geq 1, b \geq 1$, then

$$
3\left(\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{8}\right)^{2}+\frac{a b}{a+b} \geq \sqrt{\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{8}}
$$

Prove! -/
theorem inequalities_248232 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 1 ≤ a) (hb : 1 ≤ b) :
    3 * ((a ^ 2 - b ^ 2) / 8) ^ 2 + a * b / (a + b) ≥
    sqrt ((a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / 8) := by

informal_statement: The Fibonacci sequence is the sequence 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, $\ldots$ where each term is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 4?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def fib (n : ℕ) : ℕ := match n with
| 0 => 1
| 1 => 1
| n + 2 => fib n + fib (n + 1)

/- The Fibonacci sequence is the sequence 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, $\ldots$ where each term is the sum of the previous two terms. What is the remainder when the $100^{\mathrm{th}}$ term of the sequence is divided by 4? -/
theorem number_theory_19004 : fib 99 % 4 = 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

def fib (n : ℕ) : ℕ := match n with
| 0 => 1
| 1 => 1
| n + 2 => fib n + fib (n + 1)

theorem number_theory_19004 : fib 99 % 4 = 3 := by
  norm_num [fib]

soln_description:
1. **Identify the problem and given example:**
   We need to find all prime numbers \( p \) such that there exists an integer \( n \) for which there are no integers \( x \) and \( y \) satisfying \( x^3 + y^3 \equiv n \pmod{p} \). For example, for \( p = 7 \), we can set \( n = \pm 3 \) since \( x^3, y^3 \equiv 0, \pm 1 \pmod{7} \), thus \( x^3 + y^3 \equiv 0, \pm 1, \pm 2 \pmod{7} \) only.

2. **Consider primes of the form \( 3k + 1 \):**
   Suppose \( p > 7 \) is a prime of the form \( 3k + 1 \). In this case, there are \( k + 1 \) distinct cubic residues modulo \( p \).

3. **Use Davenport's theorem:**
   According to Davenport's theorem, at least \( (k + 1) + (k + 1) - 1 = 2k + 1 \) numbers can be written as the sum of two cubes modulo \( p \).

4. **Count the numbers that can be written as the sum of two cubes:**
   Since there are \( k + 1 \) cubic residues, and each residue can be multiplied by any non-zero element \( t \) in \( \mathbb{Z}_p \), there are at least \( k \) numbers that cannot be written as the sum of two cubes.

5. **Equality in Davenport's theorem:**
   Since \( p = 3k + 1 \), we have \( 2k + 1 + k = 3k + 1 = p \). This means that the equality in Davenport's theorem holds, implying that all cubic residues are of the form \( xt \) for some fixed \( t \neq 0 \) and \( a \leq x \leq a + k \).

6. **Multiplicative property of cubes:**
   Cubes are multiplicative, so for \( a \leq x, x' \leq a + k \), we have \( a \leq xx't \leq a + k \). For \( xt = -1 \), we have \( a \leq -y \leq a + k \) for all \( a \leq y \leq a + k \), implying \( a = -\frac{k}{2} \).

7. **Range of \( t \):**
   For \( x = 1 \), we have \( -\frac{k}{2} \leq t \leq \frac{k}{2} \). Since \( p > 7 \), we have \( -\frac{k}{2} \leq 2 \leq \frac{k}{2} \).

8. **Contradiction:**
   Now take \( x = 2 \) and move \( x' \) from \( 1 \) to \( \frac{k}{2} \). At some point, \( xx't \) will not be in \( [-\frac{k}{2}, \frac{k}{2}] \), leading to a contradiction.

Therefore, the only prime \( p \) for which there exists an integer \( n \) such that there are no integers \( x \) and \( y \) with \( x^3 + y^3 \equiv n \pmod{p} \) is \( p = 7 \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{7} \).
informal_statement:
Find all primes $ p$ for that there is an integer $ n$ such that there are no integers $ x,y$ with $ x^3 \plus{} y^3 \equiv n \mod p$ (so not all residues are the sum of two cubes).

E.g. for $ p \equal{} 7$, one could set $ n \equal{} \pm 3$ since $ x^3,y^3 \equiv 0 , \pm 1 \mod 7$, thus $ x^3 \plus{} y^3 \equiv 0 , \pm 1 , \pm 2 \mod 7$ only.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all primes $ p$ for that there is an integer $ n$ such that there are no integers $ x,y$ with $ x^3 \plus{} y^3 \equiv n \mod p$ (so not all residues are the sum of two cubes).

E.g. for $ p \equal{} 7$, one could set $ n \equal{} \pm 3$ since $ x^3,y^3 \equiv 0 , \pm 1 \mod 7$, thus $ x^3 \plus{} y^3 \equiv 0 , \pm 1 , \pm 2 \mod 7$ only. -/
theorem number_theory_44010 (p : ℕ) (hp : Nat.Prime p) :
    ∃ n : ℤ, ¬∃ x y : ℤ, x^3 + y^3 ≡ n [ZMOD p] ↔ p = 7 := by

soln_description:
To analyze, let $f(n)=3^{2 n}-32 n^{2}+24 n-1$. To prove that $512 \mid f(n)$, we can use the idea of recursion to instead prove that $512 \mid f(1)$, and $512 \mid(f(n+1)-f(n)), n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}$.

Proof: Let $f(n)=3^{2 n}-32 n^{2}+24 n-1$,
Since $f(1)=0$, then $512 \mid f(1)$;
Also, $f(n+1)-f(n)$
$$
=\left(3^{2 n+2}-32(n+1)^{2}+24(n+1)-1\right)-\left(3^{2 n}-32 n^{2}+24 n-1\right)=8\left(3^{2 n}-8 n-1\right) \text {. }
$$

Since $512=8 \times 64$, it is sufficient to prove that $64 \mid\left(3^{2 n}-8 n-1\right)$.
Let $g(n)=3^{2 n}-8 n-1$,
Since $g(1)=0$, then $64 \mid g(1)$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Also, } g(n+1)-g(n)=\left(3^{2 n+2}-8(n+1)-1\right)-\left(3^{2 n}-8 n-1\right)=8\left(3^{2 n}-1\right)=8\left(9^{n}-1\right) \\
=8(9-1) \cdot\left(9^{n-1}+9^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right) \\
=64\left(9^{n-1}+9^{n-2}+\cdots+1\right) .
\end{array}
$$

It is clear that, $64 \mid(g(n+1)-g(n))$,
Therefore, $64 \mid g(n)$, hence $512 \mid f(n)$.
informal_statement: Example 6 Let $n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}$, prove: $512 \mid 3^{2 n}-32 n^{2}+24 n-1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6 Let $n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}$, prove: $512 \mid 3^{2 n}-32 n^{2}+24 n-1$.

 -/
theorem number_theory_232740 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
    512 ∣ 3^(2*n) - 32*n^2 + 24*n - 1 := by

soln_description:
1. Since $v_{n}=\frac{1}{27}\left(v_{n+3}-v_{n+2}+3 v_{n+1}\right)$, by reverse induction, we can prove that for any $n \in \mathbf{N}$, $v_{n} \in \mathbf{Q}$.
In particular, $a, b, c \in \mathbf{Q}$.
Using the characteristic equation, we easily obtain the general terms of $\left\{u_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{v_{n}\right\}$ as follows:
$$
\begin{aligned}
u_{n}= & \frac{1}{2}\left((1+\sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+(1-\sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}\right), \\
v_{n}= & c_{1}(-1+2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+ \\
& c_{2}(-1-2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+c_{3} 3^{n} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then $v_{0}=c_{1}+c_{2}+c_{3}=a$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
v_{1}=(-1+2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}) c_{1}+(-1-2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}) c_{2}+3 c_{3} \\
=b,
\end{array}
$$
$$
v_{2}=(-7-4 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}) c_{1}+(-7+4 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}) c_{2}+9 c_{3}
$$
$=c$.
(2) - (1) $\times 3) \div 2$ gives
$$
\left(-2+\sqrt{2} \text { i) } c_{1}+\left(-2-\sqrt{2} \text { i) } c_{2}=m_{1}\right. \text {, }\right.
$$

where, $m_{1}=\frac{b-3 a}{2} \in \mathbf{Q}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { (3) }- \text { (1) } \times 9) \div 4 \text { gives } \\
(-4-\sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}) c_{1}+(-4+\sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}) c_{2}=m_{2},
\end{array}
$$

where, $m_{2}=\frac{c-9 a}{4} \in \mathbf{Q}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(4)+(5)) \div(-6) \text { gives } \\
c_{1}+c_{2}=m_{3},
\end{array}
$$

where, $m_{3}=\frac{m_{1}+m_{2}}{6} \in \mathbf{Q}$.
(4) $\times 2$ - (5)) $\div(3 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})$ gives
$$
c_{1}-c_{2}=m_{4} \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i} \text {, }
$$

where, $m_{4}=-\frac{2 m_{1}-m_{2}}{6} \in \mathbf{Q}$.
From equations (6) and (7), we get
$$
c_{1}=r+s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}, c_{2}=r-s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i}(r, s \in \mathbf{Q}) \text {. }
$$

From equation (1), we get $c_{3} \in \mathbf{Q}$.
Let $t=c_{3}$.
$$
\text { Hence } \begin{aligned}
v_{n}= & (r+s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})(-1+2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+ \\
& (r-s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})(-1-2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+t 3^{n} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $r, s, t \in \mathbf{Q}$, there exists a positive integer $k$ such that $k r, k s, k t \in \mathbf{Z}$.
$$
\text { Let } \begin{aligned}
w_{n}= & 2 k\left((r+s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})(1+\sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+\right. \\
& \left.(r-s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})(1-\sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $w_{0}=4 k r \in \mathbf{Z}, w_{1}=4 k(r-2 s) \in \mathbf{Z}$, and the sequence $\left\{w_{n}\right\}$ satisfies the recurrence relation
$$
w_{n}=2 w_{n-1}-3 w_{n-2}(n \geqslant 2),
$$

for any $n \in \mathbf{N}$, we have $w_{n} \in \mathbf{Z}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Hence } u_{n} w_{n}=k\left((r+s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})(-1+2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+\right. \\
\left.\quad(r-s \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})(-1-2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{i})^{n}+2 r 3^{n}\right) \\
=k v_{n}+m 3^{n}(m=k(2 r-t) \in \mathbf{Z}) . \\
\text { Thus, } m 3^{n}=u_{n} w_{n}-k v_{n} .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $m 3^{n}=u_{n} w_{n}-k v_{n}$.
When $n \geqslant N$, by $v_{n} \in \mathbf{Z}$ and $u_{n} \mid v_{n}$, we get
$u_{n} \mid m 3^{n}$.
According to the recurrence relation
$$
u_{n}=2 u_{n-1}-3 u_{n-2}(n \geqslant 2),
$$

by mathematical induction, it is easy to prove that for any $n \in \mathbf{N}$, $3 \nmid u_{n}$, i.e., $\left(u_{n}, 3^{n}\right)=1$. Therefore, $u_{n} \mid m$.
Next, we prove that the sequence $\left\{u_{n}\right\}$ has no upper bound.
By the trigonometric form of complex numbers, we have
$u_{n}=(\sqrt{3})^{n} \cos n \theta(\theta=\arctan \sqrt{2})$.
For each positive integer $n$, perform the division of $n \theta$ by $2 \pi$ with remainder, denoted as $n \theta=2 k_{n} \pi+\theta_{n}\left(k_{n}=\left[\frac{n \theta}{2 \pi}\right],[x]\right.$ represents the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $x$), there are infinitely many positive integers $n$ such that $\theta_{n} \in[0, \theta]$. For these $n$, we have
$$
\cos \theta_{n} \geqslant \cos \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow u_{n} \geqslant(\sqrt{3})^{n-1}
$$
$\Rightarrow$ the sequence $\left\{u_{n}\right\}$ has no upper bound.
If $m \neq 0$, since there exists $n \geqslant N$ such that $u_{n}>|m|$, which contradicts $u_{n} \mid m$, then $m=0$, i.e., $k v_{n}=u_{n} w_{n}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Hence } a=v_{0}=\frac{1}{k} u_{0} w_{0}=4 r, \\
b=v_{1}=\frac{1}{k} u_{1} w_{1}=4(r-2 s), \\
c=v_{2}=\frac{1}{k} u_{2} w_{2}=4(r+4 s) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $3 a=2 b+c=12 r$.
informal_statement:
1. Given the sequences $\left\{u_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{v_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
u_{0}=u_{1}=1, \\
u_{n}=2 u_{n-1}-3 u_{n-2}(n \geqslant 2) ; \\
v_{0}=a, v_{1}=b, v_{2}=c, \\
v_{n}=v_{n-1}-3 v_{n-2}+27 v_{n-3}(n \geqslant 3) .
\end{array}
$$

Assume there exists a positive integer $N$, such that for $n \geqslant N$, $v_{n}$ is an integer and divisible by $u_{n}$. Prove: $3 a=2 b+c$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Given the sequences $\left\{u_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{v_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
u_{0}=u_{1}=1, \\
u_{n}=2 u_{n-1}-3 u_{n-2}(n \geqslant 2) ; \\
v_{0}=a, v_{1}=b, v_{2}=c, \\
v_{n}=v_{n-1}-3 v_{n-2}+27 v_{n-3}(n \geqslant 3) .
\end{array}
$$

Assume there exists a positive integer $N$, such that for $n \geqslant N$, $v_{n}$ is an integer and divisible by $u_{n}$. Prove: $3 a=2 b+c$. -/
theorem algebra_296753 {u v : ℕ → ℤ} {a b c : ℤ}
    (hu01 : u 0 = 1 ∧ u 1 = 1)
    (hun : ∀ n ≥ 2, u n = 2 * u (n - 1) - 3 * u (n - 2))
    (hv012 : v 0 = a ∧ v 1 = b ∧ v 2 = c)
    (hvn : ∀ n ≥ 3, v n = v (n - 1) - 3 * v (n - 2) + 27 * v (n - 3))
    (hN : ∃ N > 0, ∀ n ≥ N, ∃ k : ℤ, v n = k ∧ u n ∣ k) :
    3 * a = 2 * b + c := by

formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_151430 : 99999 * 77778 + 33333 * 66666 = 9999900000 := by
  norm_num

informal_statement: Show that there are infinitely many odd composite numbers in the sequence $1^1, 1^1 + 2^2, 1^1 + 2^2 + 3^3, 1^1 + 2^2 + 3^3 + 4^4, ...$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that there are infinitely many odd composite numbers in the sequence $1^1, 1^1 + 2^2, 1^1 + 2^2 + 3^3, 1^1 + 2^2 + 3^3 + 4^4, ...$ . -/
theorem number_theory_41753 (a : ℕ → ℕ)
    (ha : ∀ n, a n = ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, i ^ i) :
    ∀ N, ∃ n, Odd (a n) ∧ ¬Prime (a n) ∧ a n > N := by

soln_description:
[Proof] Let $f(x)=[x]+[2 x]+[4 x]+[8 x]+[16 x]+[32 x]$.
Assume the equation has a real solution $x$, then

Also, because
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x) & =12345 . \\
f(195) & =1228512345 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then
$$
f(195)<f(x)<f(196) .
$$

Since $f(x)$ is a non-decreasing function, then
$$
195<x<196 .
$$

Let $y=x-195$, then $0<y<1$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(y) & =[x-195]+[2 x-2 \cdot 195]+\cdots+[32 x-32 \cdot 195] \\
& =f(x)-f(195) \\
& =12345-12285 \\
& =60 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $0<y<1$, for all positive integers $n$,
$$
0<n y<n \text {, }
$$

Thus
$$
[n y] \leqslant n-1 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, we also have
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(y) & =[y]+[2 y]+[4 y]+[8 y]+[16 y]+[32 y] \\
& \leqslant 0+1+3+7+15+31
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
=57 \text {. }
$$
(1) contradicts (2).

Therefore, the original equation has no real solution.
informal_statement:
$14 \cdot 9$ Prove that the equation
$$
[x]+[2 x]+[4 x]+[8 x]+[16 x]+[32 x]=12345
$$

has no real solutions.
(13th Canadian Mathematics Competition, 1981)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $14 \cdot 9$ Prove that the equation
$$
[x]+[2 x]+[4 x]+[8 x]+[16 x]+[32 x]=12345
$$

has no real solutions.
(13th Canadian Mathematics Competition, 1981) -/
theorem number_theory_153954 :
    ¬∃ x : ℝ, ⌊x⌋ + ⌊2 * x⌋ + ⌊4 * x⌋ + ⌊8 * x⌋ + ⌊16 * x⌋ + ⌊32 * x⌋ = 12345 := by

soln_description: 7. $f(x)=\sqrt{\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}-3\right)^{2}+(x-2)^{2}}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{x^{2}}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+(x-0)^{2}}$, can be regarded as the sum of the distances from a point $(x, \left.\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right)$ on the parabola $y=\frac{1}{2} x^{2}$ to two fixed points $A(2,3), B\left(0, \frac{1}{2}\right)$. Since $B$ is exactly the focus, the distance from $A$ to its directrix $\frac{7}{2}$ is the desired result.
informal_statement: 7. Find the minimum value of the function $f(x)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{4} x^{4}-2 x^{2}-4 x+13}+\frac{1}{2} x^{2}+\frac{1}{2}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 7. Find the minimum value of the function $f(x)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{4} x^{4}-2 x^{2}-4 x+13}+\frac{1}{2} x^{2}+\frac{1}{2}$. -/
theorem algebra_248563 :
  IsLeast {x | ∃ t : ℝ, x = sqrt ((1/4)*t^4 - 2*t^2 - 4*t + 13) + (1/2)*t^2 + (1/2)} (7/2) := by

soln_description:
Solve: Using the non-negativity of a quadratic function, we know that its discriminant $\Delta \leqslant 0$, thus it is easy to know that the original inequality is equivalent to
$$
(3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta-a \sin \theta-a \cos \theta)^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{4}
$$
for any $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$.
From (1), we can get $a \geqslant \frac{3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta+\frac{1}{2}}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}$, for any $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$,

or $a \leqslant \frac{3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta-\frac{1}{2}}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}$, for any $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$,
Under condition (2), since $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$, therefore $1 \leqslant \sin \theta+\cos \theta \leqslant \sqrt{2}$.
Also, $\frac{3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta+\frac{1}{2}}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}=(\sin \theta+\cos \theta)+\frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}$,
and when $1 \leqslant x \leqslant \sqrt{2}$, $f(x)=x+\frac{5}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{x}$ is a decreasing function,
so $a \geqslant \max _{\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]} \frac{3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta+\frac{1}{2}}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}=1+\frac{5}{2}=\frac{7}{2}$.
Under condition (3), since $\frac{3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta-\frac{1}{2}}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}=(\sin \theta+\cos \theta)+\frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta} \geqslant$
$2 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{3}{2}}=\sqrt{6}$, and the equality holds when $\sin \theta+\cos \theta=\frac{\sqrt{6}}{2}$, thus $\max _{\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]} \frac{3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta-\frac{1}{2}}{\sin \theta+\cos \theta}=\sqrt{6}$, hence $a \leqslant \sqrt{6}$.
In summary, we know that $a \geqslant \frac{7}{2}$ or $a \leqslant \sqrt{6}$ is the required range of $a$.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Find the range of real number $a$ such that for any real number $x$ and any $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$, the inequality $(x+$ $3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta)^{2}+(x+a \sin \theta+a \cos \theta)^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{8}$ always holds.
(1996 National High School League Question)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- Example 1 Find the range of real number $a$ such that for any real number $x$ and any $\theta \in\left[0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right]$, the inequality $(x+$ $3+2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta)^{2}+(x+a \sin \theta+a \cos \theta)^{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{8}$ always holds.
(1996 National High School League Question) -/
theorem inequalities_144931 (a : ℝ) :
  (∀ x : ℝ, ∀ θ ∈ Icc 0 (π/2), (x + 3 + 2 * sin θ * cos θ)^2 +
    (x + a * sin θ + a * cos θ)^2 ≥ 1/8) ↔ a ≥ 7/2 :=

soln_description:
SOLUTION. From the obvious inequality $(\sqrt{x}-1)^{4} \geq 0$, we see that
$$\frac{1+x^{2}}{2} \leq(x-\sqrt{x}+1)^{2} \Rightarrow \sqrt{\frac{1+x^{2}}{2}}+\sqrt{x} \leq 1+x$$

According to this result, we have of course
$$\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{1+a_{i}^{2}} \leq \sqrt{2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}+\sqrt{2}\left(n-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{a_{i}}\right) \leq \sqrt{2}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)$$
because AM-GM inequality yields that $\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{a_{i}} \geq n$. The conclusion follows and equality holds if $a_{1}=a_{2}=\ldots=a_{n}=1$.
informal_statement:
Problem 8. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}=1$. Prove that
$$\sqrt{1+a_{1}^{2}}+\sqrt{1+a_{2}^{2}}+\ldots+\sqrt{1+a_{n}^{2}} \leq \sqrt{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Problem 8. Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be positive real numbers and $a_{1} a_{2} \ldots a_{n}=1$. Prove that
$$\sqrt{1+a_{1}^{2}}+\sqrt{1+a_{2}^{2}}+\ldots+\sqrt{1+a_{n}^{2}} \leq \sqrt{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{n}\right)$$ -/
theorem inequalities_601925 (n : ℕ) (a : Fin n → ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ i, 0 < a i) (h₁ : ∏ i, a i = 1) :
    ∑ i, sqrt (1 + (a i)^2) ≤ sqrt 2 * ∑ i, a i := by

soln_description:
$y=0$ on a $f(-1)+f(x) f(0)=-1$ as $f$ is not constant we have $f(0)=0, f(-1)=-1$. Then we set $y=1$ and we have $f(x-1)+f(x) f(1)=2 x-1$ and with $y=\frac{1}{x}$ we get $f(x) f\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)=1$. So $f(1)=1$ or -1.

We set $y=\frac{1}{x-1}$ and we have $f\left(\frac{1}{x-1}\right)(1+f(x))=\frac{x+1}{x-1}$ for $x \neq 1$.

Then we multiply by $f(x-1)$ and $1+f(x)=\frac{x+1}{x-1} f(x-1)$. In short, we substitute, if $f(1)=1$ we get the identity which is a solution, otherwise we have $f(x)=-x^{2}$ which is also a solution.
informal_statement:
(Hungary 2017)(D) Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that, for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
f(x y-1)+f(x) f(y)=2 x y-1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (Hungary 2017)(D) Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that, for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$,

$$
f(x y-1)+f(x) f(y)=2 x y-1
$$ -/
theorem algebra_163283 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (h : ∀ x y, f (x * y - 1) + f x * f y = 2 * x * y - 1) :
    (∀ x, f x = x) ∨ (∀ x, f x = -x ^ 2) := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let the radius of the base circle of the cone be $r$, its height be $m$, and its slant height be $a$. Then $V=\frac{r^{2} \pi m}{3}=1, r^{2}=\frac{3}{m \pi}$. According to the Pythagorean theorem,

$$
a=\sqrt{r^{2}+m^{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{m \pi}+m^{2}}
$$

The surface area of the cone is:

$$
A=r^{2} \pi+r \pi a=\frac{3}{m \pi} \cdot \pi+\sqrt{\frac{3}{m \pi}} \cdot \pi \cdot \sqrt{\frac{3}{m \pi}+m^{2}}=\frac{3}{m}+\pi \cdot \sqrt{\frac{9}{m^{2} \pi^{2}}+\frac{3 m}{\pi}}
$$

Rearranging:

$$
A-\frac{3}{m}=\sqrt{\frac{9}{m^{2}}+3 m \pi}
$$

Since $A \geq \frac{3}{m}$, we can square both sides:

$$
A^{2}-\frac{6 A}{m}+\frac{9}{m^{2}}=\frac{9}{m^{2}}+3 m \pi, \quad A^{2} m-6 A=3 m^{2} \pi, \quad 3 m^{2} \pi-A^{2} m+6 A=0
$$

Thus,

$$
m_{1,2}=\frac{A^{2} \pm \sqrt{A^{4}-72 A \pi}}{6 \pi}
$$

The discriminant must be non-negative, so

$$
A^{4}-72 A \pi \geq 0, \quad \text { i.e., } \quad A \geq \sqrt[3]{72 \pi}
$$

Therefore, the minimum surface area is $A=\sqrt[3]{72 \pi}$.

In this case, $D=0$, so

$$
\begin{aligned}
& m=\frac{A^{2}}{6 \pi}=\frac{\sqrt[3]{(72 \pi)^{2}}}{6 \pi}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{72^{2} \cdot \pi^{2}}{6^{3} \cdot \pi^{3}}}=2 \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{\pi}} \\
& r^{2}=\frac{3}{m \pi}=\frac{3}{\pi \cdot 2 \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{\pi}}}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{3^{3}}{\pi^{3} \cdot 2^{3} \cdot \frac{3}{\pi}}}=\sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{2^{3} \cdot \pi^{2}}}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{9}{\pi^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $r=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{\pi}}$

Therefore, among the cones with a unit volume, the one with the smallest surface area has a height of $2 \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{\pi}}$ and a base radius of $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \sqrt[3]{\frac{3}{\pi}}$.
informal_statement: Among the unit volume frustums of revolution, which one has the minimum surface area?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Among the unit volume frustums of revolution, which one has the minimum surface area? -/
theorem calculus_224507 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf : f = λ x => x ^ (2 / 3) * π) :
  IsLeast {x | ∃ t, x = f t} (72 * π ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3)) :=

soln_description:
We claim that the squares which work are $4^{k+1}$ or $9 \cdot 4^{k}$ for $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$. These work because $4^{k+1}=2^{2 k+1}+2^{2 k+1}$ and $9 \cdot 4^{k}=2^{2 k+3}+2^{2 k}$.

Write $n^{2}=2^{a}+2^{b}$ for $n, a, b \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$ and $a \geq b$. If $a=b, n^{2}=2^{b+1}$, and since the perfect squares that are powers of two are the powers of 4 , we have $n=4^{k+1}$ for some $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}$.

Otherwise, $a-b>0$ so $2^{a-b}$ is even and $2^{a-b}+1$ is odd. Therefore, $2^{b}$ and $2^{a-b}+1$ are relatively prime, so since $n^{2}=2^{a}+2^{b}=2^{b}\left(2^{a-b}+1\right), 2^{b}$ and $2^{a-b}+1$ are perfect squares, so $2^{b}$ is a power of 4 . Let $m^{2}=2^{a-b}+1$, so $(m-1)(m+1)=2^{a-b}$. Then, $m-1$ and $m+1$ are powers of 2 that differ by 2 . By inspection, we see that $m=3$ so $2^{a-b}+1=9$ and $n^{2}$ is 9 times a power of 4 , as desired.
informal_statement: Find all perfect squares that can be written as the sum of two powers of 2.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all perfect squares that can be written as the sum of two powers of 2. -/
theorem number_theory_255038 (n : ℕ) :
    IsSquare n ∧ ∃ k l, n = 2^k + 2^l ↔ ∃ m, n = m^2 ∧ ∃ k, n = 4^(k + 1) := by

soln_description:
Assume that the given equation has solutions in real numbers: let $ \alpha $ be one of these solutions. Of course, $ \alpha $ cannot be an integer multiple of $ \pi/2 $, because for such numbers the right side loses its meaning. According to the equation,






hence $ 2\sin n\alpha \cdot \sin 2\alpha=2 $, which means






(we use the formula: $ \cos u - \cos v = 2\sin \frac{1}{2}(u+v)\sin\frac{1}{2}(v-u)) $. The difference of two cosines is equal to $ 2 $ if and only if the first one has the value $ 1 $ and the second one $ -1 $. We thus obtain the system of equalities






from which it follows that






($ p, q $ are integers).
In the second of the equalities (1), we have a non-zero number on the right side; hence the left side also has a non-zero value. We can therefore divide the first equality by the second. We get the relation $ \frac{n-2}{n+2}=\frac{2q}{2p+1} $.
By introducing the notation $ n-2 = m $, we rewrite this relation as $ (2p+1)m = 2q(m+4) $, or






We see that the number $ m $ multiplied by an odd number gives a result divisible by $ 8 $, which is possible only if the number $ m $ itself is divisible by $ 8 $. Since $ n = m + 2 $, this means that the number $ n $ gives a remainder of $ 2 $ when divided by $ 8 $.
Taking into account the condition of the problem that the number $ n $ must be positive, we arrive at the following conclusion:






Conversely, if the number $ n $ has such a form, then the considered equation has solutions in real numbers --- one of them is, for example, the number $ x = \frac{1}{4} \pi $; indeed: for $ x=\frac{1}{4} \pi $ and $ n = 8k + 2 $ we have $ nx = 2k\pi + \frac{1}{2} \pi $, from which $ \sin nx = 1 $; both the left and the right side of the equation have the value $ 2 $.
Conclusion: the numbers whose determination was the goal of the problem are characterized by the statement (2).
Note: We will also mention a variant of the solution based on the observation (right at the beginning) that for any number $ x $ the right side of the equation, as a number of the form $ t + (1/t) $, has an absolute value not less than $ 2 $, while the absolute value of the left side is not greater than $ 2 $. The equation can therefore be satisfied only when both sides have the value $ 2 $ or $ -2 $. Each of these possibilities gives a system of two simple trigonometric equations. Completing the reasoning is an easy task and leads to conclusion (2), which characterizes the sought numbers $ n $. We leave the elaboration of the details to the reader.
informal_statement:
XLVII OM - I - Problem 1

Determine all integers $ n $ for which the equation $ 2 \sin nx = \tan x + \cot x $ has solutions in real numbers $ x $.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- XLVII OM - I - Problem 1

Determine all integers $ n $ for which the equation $ 2 \sin nx = \tan x + \cot x $ has solutions in real numbers $ x $. -/
theorem algebra_121721 (n : ℤ) :
  (∃ x : ℝ, 2 * sin (n * x) = tan x + 1 / tan x) ↔ ∃ k : ℤ, n = 8 * k + 2 := by

soln_description:
43. We can write the given equation in the form
$$
x^{5}-x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x-2+\lambda\left(5 x^{4}+\alpha x^{2}-8 x+\alpha\right)=0 .
$$

A root of this equation is independent of $\lambda$ if and only if it is a common root of the equations
$$
x^{5}-x^{3}-4 x^{2}-3 x-2=0 \quad \text { and } \quad 5 x^{4}+\alpha x^{2}-8 x+\alpha=0 .
$$

The first of these two equations is equivalent to $(x-2)\left(x^{2}+x+1\right)^{2}=0$ and has three different roots: $x_{1}=2, x_{2,3}=(-1 \pm i \sqrt{3}) / 2$.
(a) For $\alpha=-64 / 5, x_{1}=2$ is the unique root independent of $\lambda$.
(b) For $\alpha=-3$ there are two roots independent of $\lambda$ : $x_{1}=\omega$ and $x_{2}=\omega^{2}$.
informal_statement:
43. (ROM 2) The equation
$$
x^{5}+5 \lambda x^{4}-x^{3}+(\lambda \alpha-4) x^{2}-(8 \lambda+3) x+\lambda \alpha-2=0
$$
is given.
(a) Determine $\alpha$ such that the given equation has exactly one root independent of $\lambda$.
(b) Determine $\alpha$ such that the given equation has exactly two roots independent of $\lambda$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 43. (ROM 2) The equation
$$
x^{5}+5 \lambda x^{4}-x^{3}+(\lambda \alpha-4) x^{2}-(8 \lambda+3) x+\lambda \alpha-2=0
$$
is given.
(a) Determine $\alpha$ such that the given equation has exactly one root independent of $\lambda$.
(b) Determine $\alpha$ such that the given equation has exactly two roots independent of $\lambda$. -/
theorem algebra_255047 (α : ℝ) (h : ∀ lambda : ℝ, ∃! x : ℝ, x^5 + 5 * lambda * x^4 - x^3 + (lambda * α - 4) * x^2 - (8 * lambda + 3) * x + lambda * α - 2 = 0) :
    α = -64 / 5 := by

soln_description:
2. C

Given $b+c \geqslant a+d$, then $b+c \geqslant \frac{1}{2}(a+b+c+d)$. Without loss of generality, assume $a+b \geqslant c+d$, then $\frac{1}{c+d} \geqslant \frac{1}{a+b}$. Therefore,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{b}{c+d}+\frac{c}{a+b}=\frac{b+c}{c+d}-c\left(\frac{1}{c+d}-\frac{1}{a+b}\right) \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{a+b+c+d}{c+d}-(c+d)\left[\frac{1}{c+d}-\frac{1}{a+b}\right] \\
=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{a+b}{c+d}+\frac{c+d}{a+b}-\frac{1}{2} \\
\geqslant 2 \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{a+b}{c+d} \cdot \frac{c+d}{a+b}}-\frac{1}{2}=\sqrt{2}-\frac{1}{2} .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
2. Let $a, d$ be non-negative real numbers, $b, c$ be positive real numbers, and $b+c \geqslant a+d$. Then the minimum value of $\frac{b}{c+d}+\frac{c}{a+b}$ is ( ).
(A) 1
(B) $\frac{1}{2}$
(C) $\sqrt{2}-\frac{1}{2}$
(D) $\sqrt{2}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- 2. Let $a, d$ be non-negative real numbers, $b, c$ be positive real numbers, and $b+c \geqslant a+d$. Then the minimum value of $\frac{b}{c+d}+\frac{c}{a+b}$ is ( ).
(A) 1
(B) $\frac{1}{2}$
(C) $\sqrt{2}-\frac{1}{2}$
(D) $\sqrt{2}$ -/
theorem inequalities_304859 (a d : ℝ) (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hd : 0 ≤ d)
    (b c : ℝ) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (h : b + c ≥ a + d) :
    b / (c + d) + c / (a + b) ≥ sqrt 2 - 1 / 2 := by

informal_statement: Let $x,$ $y,$ $z$ be positive real numbers such that $xyz = 8.$  Find the minimum value of $x + 2y + 4z.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $x,$ $y,$ $z$ be positive real numbers such that $xyz = 8.$  Find the minimum value of $x + 2y + 4z.$ -/
theorem algebra_13437 :
    IsLeast {a | ∃ x y z : ℝ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ z > 0 ∧ x * y * z = 8 ∧ a = x + 2 * y + 4 * z} 12 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem algebra_13437 :
    IsLeast {a | ∃ x y z : ℝ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ z > 0 ∧ x * y * z = 8 ∧ a = x + 2 * y + 4 * z} 12 := by
  constructor
  · -- Show 12 is in the set
    use 4, 2, 1
    norm_num
  · -- Show no number less than 12 is in the set
    intro a h
    rcases h with ⟨x, y, z, hx, hy, hz, h1, ha⟩
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 4), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (z - 1),
      mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz,
      sq_nonneg ((x / 4) - 1), sq_nonneg ((y / 2) - 1), sq_nonneg ((z / 1) - 1)]

soln_description:
Problem 15. The answer is (D).

The statement is equivalent to saying that $x$ is a multiple of $1, 2, 3,$ and $4$, but not of $5$. We need to count the positive integers less than 2016 that are multiples of 12, but not of 60. Since $2016 / 12 = 168$, and $2016 / 60 = 33$, there will be exactly $168 - 33 = 135$.

(Problem proposed by E. Tron)
informal_statement:
15. Observing the calendar, Chiara noticed that the current year 2016 has a particularity: if $x=2016$ is the year number, then $x+1$ is a multiple of $1, x+2$ is a multiple of $2, x+3$ is a multiple of 3, and $x+4$ is a multiple of 4, but $x+5$ is not a multiple of 5. How many other positive integers, less than 2016, have the same particularity?
(A) 141
(B) 83
(C) 167
(D) 134
(E) 149
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 15. Observing the calendar, Chiara noticed that the current year 2016 has a particularity: if $x=2016$ is the year number, then $x+1$ is a multiple of $1, x+2$ is a multiple of $2, x+3$ is a multiple of 3, and $x+4$ is a multiple of 4, but $x+5$ is not a multiple of 5. How many other positive integers, less than 2016, have the same particularity?
(A) 141
(B) 83
(C) 167
(D) 134
(E) 149 -/
theorem number_theory_128611 :
    Set.ncard {x : ℕ | x < 2016 ∧ (x + 1) % 1 = 0 ∧ (x + 2) % 2 = 0 ∧ (x + 3) % 3 = 0 ∧ (x + 4) % 4 = 0 ∧ ¬(x + 5) % 5 = 0} = 134 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_128611 :
    Set.ncard {x : ℕ | x < 2016 ∧ (x + 1) % 1 = 0 ∧ (x + 2) % 2 = 0 ∧ (x + 3) % 3 = 0 ∧ (x + 4) % 4 = 0 ∧ ¬(x + 5) % 5 = 0} = 134 := by 
  have h1 : {x : ℕ | x < 2016 ∧ (x + 1) % 1 = 0 ∧ (x + 2) % 2 = 0 ∧ (x + 3) % 3 = 0 ∧ (x + 4) % 4 = 0 ∧ ¬(x + 5) % 5 = 0} = Finset.filter (fun x => x < 2016 ∧ (x + 1) % 1 = 0 ∧ (x + 2) % 2 = 0 ∧ (x + 3) % 3 = 0 ∧ (x + 4) % 4 = 0 ∧ ¬(x + 5) % 5 = 0) (Finset.Icc 0 2015) := by
    ext x 
    simp 
    <;> omega 
  rw [h1]
  rw [Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
  native_decide

soln_description:
Each of the graphs consists of two orthogonal half-lines. In the first graph both point downwards at a $45^\circ$ angle, in the second graph they point upwards. One can easily find out that the only way how to get these graphs to intersect in two points is the one depicted below:


Obviously, the maximum of the first graph is achieved when $x=a$, and its value is $-0+b=b$. Similarly, the minimum of the other graph is $(c,d)$. Therefore the two remaining vertices of the area between the graphs are $(a,b)$ and $(c,d)$.
As the area has four right angles, it is a rectangle. Without actually computing $a$ and $c$ we can therefore conclude that $a+c=2+8=\boxed{10}$.

Explanation of the last step
This is a property all rectangles in the coordinate plane have. 
For a proof, note that for any rectangle $ABCD$ its center can be computed as $(A+C)/2$ and at the same time as $(B+D)/2$. In our case, we can compute that the center is $\left(\frac{2+8}2,\frac{5+3}2\right)=(5,4)$, therefore $\frac{a+c}2=5$, and $a+c=10$.


An alternate last step
We can easily compute $a$ and $c$ using our picture. 


Consider the first graph on the interval $[2,8]$. The graph starts at height $5$, then rises for $a-2$ steps to the height $b=5+(a-2)$, and then falls for $8-a$ steps to the height $3=5+(a-2)-(8-a)$. Solving for $a$ we get $a=4$. Similarly we compute $c=6$, therefore $a+c=10$.
informal_statement:
The graphs of $y = -|x-a| + b$ and $y = |x-c| + d$ intersect at points $(2,5)$ and $(8,3)$. Find $a+c$.
$\mathrm{(A) \ } 7 \qquad \mathrm{(B) \ } 8 \qquad \mathrm{(C) \ } 10 \qquad \mathrm{(D) \ } 13\qquad \mathrm{(E) \ } 18$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The graphs of $y = -|x-a| + b$ and $y = |x-c| + d$ intersect at points $(2,5)$ and $(8,3)$. Find $a+c$.
$\mathrm{(A) \ } 7 \qquad \mathrm{(B) \ } 8 \qquad \mathrm{(C) \ } 10 \qquad \mathrm{(D) \ } 13\qquad \mathrm{(E) \ } 18$ -/
theorem algebra_94139 {a b c d : ℝ} (h₁ : -abs (2 - a) + b = abs (2 - c) + d)
    (h₂ : -abs (8 - a) + b = abs (8 - c) + d) : a + c = 10 := by

soln_description: answer: 6
informal_statement: 56. If $a$ is the integer part of $\sqrt{17}-2$, $b-1$ is the square root of 9, and $|a-b|=b-a$, then the value of $a+b$ is $\qquad$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 56. If $a$ is the integer part of $\sqrt{17}-2$, $b-1$ is the square root of 9, and $|a-b|=b-a$, then the value of $a+b$ is $\qquad$. -/
theorem algebra_108657 {a b : ℤ} (ha : a = ⌊Real.sqrt 17 - 2⌋) (hb : b - 1 = Real.sqrt 9)
    (h : |a - b| = b - a) : a + b = 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_108657 {a b : ℤ} (ha : a = ⌊Real.sqrt 17 - 2⌋) (hb : b - 1 = Real.sqrt 9)
    (h : |a - b| = b - a) : a + b = 6 := by
  -- We need to determine the integer part of sqrt(17) - 2
  have h1 : a = 2 := by
    rw [ha]
    have h2 : 4 < Real.sqrt 17 := by
      rw [Real.lt_sqrt] <;> norm_num
    have h3 : Real.sqrt 17 < 5 := by
      rw [Real.sqrt_lt] <;> norm_num
    -- From 4 < sqrt(17) < 5, we derive 2 < sqrt(17) - 2 < 3
    have h4 : 2 < Real.sqrt 17 - 2 := by
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 17, Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ 17 by norm_num)]
    have h5 : Real.sqrt 17 - 2 < (3 : ℝ) := by
      nlinarith [Real.sqrt_nonneg 17, Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ℝ) ≤ 17 by norm_num)]
    rw [Int.floor_eq_iff]
    constructor <;> (try norm_num) <;> nlinarith
  -- Real.sqrt 9 is equal to 3 because 9 is a perfect square
  have h6 : Real.sqrt 9 = (3 : ℝ) := by
    rw [Real.sqrt_eq_cases]
    norm_num
  -- Given b - 1 = Real.sqrt 9, we can deduce b = 4
  have h7 : (b : ℝ) - 1 = (3 : ℝ) := by
    rw [h6] at hb
    exact_mod_cast hb
  have h8 : b = 4 := by
    have h9 : (b : ℝ) = (4 : ℝ) := by
      linarith
    exact_mod_cast h9
  -- With a = 2 and b = 4, we need to verify |a - b| = b - a|
  rw [h1, h8] at h
  norm_num [abs_of_nonneg, abs_of_nonpos] at h
  -- Final calculation of a + b
  linarith [h1, h8]

soln_description:
1. **Base Case:**
   We start with the base case where \( k = 0 \). For any \( a \in [0, 1] \), we have:
   \[
   f_0(a) + f_0(1-a) = a + (1-a) = 1
   \]
   This satisfies the desired property.

2. **Inductive Step:**
   Assume that for some \( k = j \), the property holds:
   \[
   f_j(a) + f_j(1-a) = 1
   \]
   We need to show that this property holds for \( k = j+1 \). By the definition of the function sequence, we have:
   \[
   f_{j+1}(x) = f_j(x^2(3-2x))
   \]
   Therefore, we need to show:
   \[
   f_{j+1}(a) + f_{j+1}(1-a) = f_j(a^2(3-2a)) + f_j((1-a)^2(3-2(1-a)))
   \]
   Simplifying the argument of the second term:
   \[
   (1-a)^2(3-2(1-a)) = (1-a)^2(3-2+2a) = (1-a)^2(1+2a) = (1-a)^2 + 2a(1-a)^2
   \]
   Further simplifying:
   \[
   (1-a)^2 + 2a(1-a)^2 = 1 - 2a + a^2 + 2a(1 - 2a + a^2) = 1 - 2a + a^2 + 2a - 4a^2 + 2a^3 = 1 - 3a^2 + 2a^3
   \]
   Thus, we have:
   \[
   f_{j+1}(a) + f_{j+1}(1-a) = f_j(a^2(3-2a)) + f_j(1 - a^2(3-2a))
   \]
   Let \( b = a^2(3-2a) \). Then:
   \[
   f_j(b) + f_j(1-b) = 1
   \]
   by the inductive hypothesis. This completes the induction.

3. **Summation:**
   Since \( f_k(a) + f_k(1-a) = 1 \) for all \( k \) and \( a \in [0, 1] \), we have:
   \[
   \sum_{n=0}^{2017} f_n(a) + \sum_{n=0}^{2017} f_n(1-a) = \sum_{n=0}^{2017} 1 = 2018
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{2018}\)
informal_statement:
Let $f_{0}(x)=x$, and for each $n\geq 0$, let $f_{n+1}(x)=f_{n}(x^{2}(3-2x))$. Find the smallest real number that is at least as large as
\[ \sum_{n=0}^{2017} f_{n}(a) + \sum_{n=0}^{2017} f_{n}(1-a)\]
for all $a \in [0,1]$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $f_{0}(x)=x$, and for each $n\geq 0$, let $f_{n+1}(x)=f_{n}(x^{2}(3-2x))$. Find the smallest real number that is at least as large as
\[ \sum_{n=0}^{2017} f_{n}(a) + \sum_{n=0}^{2017} f_{n}(1-a)\]
for all $a \in [0,1]$. -/
theorem other_65183 (f : ℕ → ℝ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ x, f 0 x = x)
  (h₁ : ∀ n x, f (n + 1) x = f n (x ^ 2 * (3 - 2 * x))) :
  IsLeast {x | ∀ a ∈ Icc 0 1, x ≥ ∑ n in Finset.range 2018, f n a + ∑ n in Finset.range 2018, f n (1 - a)} 2018 := by

soln_description:
1. **Initial Assumptions and Setup:**
   Given the equation \(a^{2014} + b^{2014} + c^{2014} + abc = 4\), we need to prove the inequality:
   \[
   \frac{a^{2013} + b^{2013} - c}{c^{2013}} + \frac{b^{2013} + c^{2013} - a}{a^{2013}} + \frac{c^{2013} + a^{2013} - b}{b^{2013}} \ge a^{2012} + b^{2012} + c^{2012}.
   \]

2. **Analyzing the Given Condition:**
   Notice that since \(a, b, c\) are positive reals, and \(a^{2014} + b^{2014} + c^{2014} + abc = 4\), we can infer that at least one of \(a, b, c\) must be greater than or equal to 1, and at least one must be less than or equal to 1. Without loss of generality, assume \(a \ge 1\) and \(b \le 1\).

3. **Inequality Manipulation:**
   Consider the expression \((a^{2013} - 1)(b^{2013} - 1)\):
   \[
   (a^{2013} - 1)(b^{2013} - 1) \le 0 \implies a^{2013} + b^{2013} \ge (ab)^{2013} + 1.
   \]
   Similarly, for the reciprocals:
   \[
   \frac{1}{a^{2013}} + \frac{1}{b^{2013}} \ge \frac{1}{(ab)^{2013}} + 1.
   \]

4. **Combining Inequalities:**
   Using the above results, we can write:
   \[
   (a^{2013} + b^{2013} + c^{2013} - 1)\left(\frac{1}{a^{2013}} + \frac{1}{b^{2013}} + \frac{1}{c^{2013}} - 1\right) \ge 4.
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   \frac{b^{2013} + c^{2013}}{a^{2013}} + \frac{c^{2013} + a^{2013}}{b^{2013}} + \frac{a^{2013} + b^{2013}}{c^{2013}} \ge a^{2013} + b^{2013} + c^{2013} + \frac{1}{a^{2013}} + \frac{1}{b^{2013}} + \frac{1}{c^{2013}}.
   \]

5. **Final Step:**
   Since \(f(x) = x + \frac{1}{x}\) is a decreasing function on the interval \([0, 1]\), we have:
   \[
   a^{2013} + \frac{1}{a^{2013}} + b^{2013} + \frac{1}{b^{2013}} + c^{2013} + \frac{1}{c^{2013}} \ge a^{2012} + b^{2012} + c^{2012} + \frac{1}{a^{2012}} + \frac{1}{b^{2012}} + \frac{1}{c^{2012}}.
   \]
   Therefore, we conclude:
   \[
   \frac{a^{2013} + b^{2013} - c}{c^{2013}} + \frac{b^{2013} + c^{2013} - a}{a^{2013}} + \frac{c^{2013} + a^{2013} - b}{b^{2013}} \ge a^{2012} + b^{2012} + c^{2012}.
   \]

\(\blacksquare\)

Solution. We will select all odd numbers from 673 to 2015, their quantity is

$\frac{2015-671}{2}=672$. None of these numbers is divisible by another, because in division, the result should be an odd number, which is at least 3, but $673-3>2015$.

We will show that it is impossible to select more than 672 numbers satisfying the condition of the problem. Indeed, let's divide all odd numbers from 17 to 2015 into 672 groups, generated by the selected numbers and including the generating number and all its divisors, such that the result of division by which is a power of three: $\{2015\},\{2013,671\},\{2011\},\{2009\},\{2007,669,223\}, \ldots,\{675,225, 75,25\},\{673\}$. If more than 672 numbers are selected, then by the pigeonhole principle, at least two of them will end up in the same group, meaning one of them will be divisible by the other.

Note that the selected set of 672 numbers is not unique. For example, if we replace the number $2013=671 \cdot 3$ with 671, the new set will also satisfy the condition of the problem.

Answer variant 1: 672. Suitable, for example, the set 673,..., 2015.

Answer variant 2: 667. Suitable, for example, the set 669, ..., 1999.

Answer variant 3: 673. Suitable, for example, the set 673, ..., 2017.

Answer variant 4: 670. Suitable, for example, the set 671, ..., 2009.

Scoring criteria: 15 points - correct reasoning and correct answer, 10 points - correct answer and a correct example provided, but no proof that more numbers cannot be selected.

informal_statement: 8. What is the least number of odd numbers that can be chosen from the set of all odd numbers lying between 16 and 2016, so that no one of the chosen numbers is divisible by any other?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. What is the least number of odd numbers that can be chosen from the set of all odd numbers lying between 16 and 2016, so that no one of the chosen numbers is divisible by any other?

 -/
theorem number_theory_201228 :
    IsLeast {n | ∃ s : Finset ℕ, s.card = n ∧
      (∀ m ∈ s, Odd m ∧ 16 ≤ m ∧ m < 2016) ∧
      (∀ m ∈ s, ∀ n ∈ s, m ≠ n → ¬(m ∣ n))} 672 := by

informal_statement: $P$ and $Q$ represent numbers, and $P \ast Q$ means $\cfrac{P+Q}{2}$. What is the value of $3 \ast (6 \ast 8)$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- $P$ and $Q$ represent numbers, and $P \ast Q$ means $\cfrac{P+Q}{2}$. What is the value of $3 \ast (6 \ast 8)$? -/
theorem algebra_18602 {f : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x y, f x y = (x + y) / 2) :
    f 3 (f 6 8) = 5 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Finset

theorem algebra_18602 {f : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x y, f x y = (x + y) / 2) :
    f 3 (f 6 8) = 5 := by
  have h1 : f 6 8 = 7 := by 
    rw [hf]
    norm_num
  rw [h1]
  rw [hf]
  norm_num

soln_description:
## Solution.

The conditions for the solution of the equation are $x \neq 0, x \neq -1$.

By simplifying the denominator of the fraction on the left side of the equation step by step, we get:

$\frac{a}{1-\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{x}}}=2023 x$

$\frac{a}{1-\frac{1}{\frac{x+1}{x}}}=2023 x$

$\frac{a}{1-\frac{x}{x+1}}=2023 x$

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_30_5ec97620b8cc23e4b297g-03.jpg?height=149&width=848&top_left_y=1439&top_left_x=181)

Then, $a x + a = 2023 x$, which simplifies to

$x(2023 - a) = a$.

For $a = 2023$, the equation becomes $0 \cdot x = 2023$, so the equation has no solution.

For $a \neq 2023$, the solution to the original equation is $x = \frac{a}{2023 - a} \left(^{*}\right)$, but the original equation will not have a solution if the obtained solution $x$ does not satisfy the initial conditions.

The value of $a$ for which this can happen can be found by substituting $x = 0$ and $x = -1$ into $\left(^{*}\right)$.

In the first case, we get $a = 0$, and the second case is impossible.

Therefore, the given equation will not have a solution if $a = 0$ and if $a = 2023$.

Note: The student does not need to write the initial conditions if they have verified the result at the end and written the correct solution. If they have not written the conditions and only have the solution $a = 2023$, they can receive a maximum of 4 points.
informal_statement:
## Task B-1.4.

Determine all real numbers $a$ for which the equation

$$
\frac{a}{1-\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{x}}}=2023 x
$$

has no solutions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task B-1.4.

Determine all real numbers $a$ for which the equation

$$
\frac{a}{1-\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{x}}}=2023 x
$$

has no solutions. -/
theorem algebra_209607 (a : ℝ) :
    ¬∃ x : ℝ, x ≠ 0 ∧ a / (1 - 1 / (1 + 1 / x)) = 2023 * x ↔ a = 02023 := by

informal_statement:
Prove that for $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the following identity holds:
\[
\cot^{2} \frac{\pi}{2n+1} + \cot^{2} \frac{2\pi}{2n+1} + \cot^{2} \frac{3\pi}{2n+1} + \cdots + \cot^{2} \frac{n\pi}{2n+1} = \frac{n(2n-1)}{3}.
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real

/- Prove that for $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the following identity holds:
\[
\cot^{2} \frac{\pi}{2n+1} + \cot^{2} \frac{2\pi}{2n+1} + \cot^{2} \frac{3\pi}{2n+1} + \cdots + \cot^{2} \frac{n\pi}{2n+1} = \frac{n(2n-1)}{3}.
\] -/
theorem algebra_3156 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
  ∑ k ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, (cot (k * π / (2 * n + 1)))^2 = n * (2 * n - 1) / 3 := by

informal_statement: A circle has an area of $M\text{ cm}^2$ and a circumference of $N\text{ cm}$. If $\dfrac{M}{N}=20$, what is the radius of the circle, in cm?

theorem algebra_10981 {r : ℝ} (hr : r > 0) (h : (π * r^2) / (2 * π * r) = 20) :
    r = 40 := by
